title: China, US agree to 90-day tariff cuts ahead of more talks to defuse trade war
content: US President Donald Trump said he would likely speak to Chinese President Xi Jinping later this week. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen:
China and the United States have both agreed to slash reciprocal tariffs on each other and to commit to trade talks.

For 90 days from May 14, the US will effectively cut tariffs on imports from China to 30 per cent from 145 per cent, while China will reduce tariffs on US goods to 10 per cent from 125 per cent.

US President Donald Trump said he would likely speak to Chinese leader Xi Jinping later this week.

The world‚Äôs two largest economies said in a joint statement on May 12 after two days of talks in Geneva that they recognised ‚Äúthe importance of their bilateral economic and trade relationship to both countries and the global economy‚Äù.

China will also hold off or remove all non-tariff countermeasures it has taken against the US since April 2, the statement said.

China and the US have pledged to ‚Äúcontinue discussions about economic and trade relations‚Äù during the 90-day pause.

These negotiations will be fronted by China‚Äôs Vice-Premier He Lifeng, the country‚Äôs economic czar, and US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer.

Mr He, Mr Bessent and Mr Greer had met in Geneva in Switzerland in the first publicly known trade talks between both sides since the US ratcheted up tariffs on Chinese goods in April.

Both Mr He and Mr Bessent separately told the press on May 12 that the meetings had achieved ‚Äúsubstantial progress‚Äù.

The latest agreement between China and the US marks a significant de-escalation from a trade war.

The latest trade war between the US and China started in February, when Mr Trump slapped new tariffs on Chinese imports.

Eventually, the US hiked tariffs on goods from China to 145 per cent, and China responded by slapping tariffs of 125 per cent on US imports.

Throughout the latest trade war, China had promised to ‚Äúfight to the end‚Äù.

Mr Trump had also imposed a baseline tariff rate of 10 per cent on all countries that took effect on April 5.

Risks from the US trade tariffs led the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to warn in April of a worsening global outlook, as the financial agency sharply lowered its economic forecast for 2025 and 2026.

For 2025, the IMF expects global growth to come in at 2.8 per cent, lower than its January forecast of 3.3 per cent.

It also lowered its forecast for 2026 to 3 per cent, trimming 0.3 percentage points from its earlier estimate.

title: These locals want Trump to win the battle for the Panama Canal
content: Huddled together on a dirt bank outside a building site on the edge of the Panama Canal, the men shout fervidly about Donald Trump.
resumen:
The Panama Canal has become a political issue.

Some construction workers are cheering for Donald Trump, who pledged to "take back" the waterway. They believe the canal benefits only a few "elites" and want Trump's intervention.

Trump has claimed the canal is under Chinese control.

A Hong Kong-based firm, CK Hutchison Holdings, manages two ports adjacent to the canal. The Trump administration has pressured the firm to sell those interests to a US consortium that includes BlackRock Inc.

A Chinese spokesman insisted the country "will as always respect Panama‚Äôs sovereignty".

A Chinese consortium won a $1.4 billion contract to build the canal‚Äôs fourth bridge. Local workmen claim they have been disregarded in favor of foreigners.

Marvin Moreno, a welder, supports Trump.

Trump has criticized former president Jimmy Carter for returning the canal to Panama.

The US is the canal‚Äôs biggest user, with some 40 per cent of all US container traffic crossing it each year.

Trump dispatched Marco Rubio and Pete Hegseth to Panama. Hegseth delivered a press conference stating: ‚ÄúWe will take back the Panama Canal from China‚Äôs influence.‚Äù

Following Rubio‚Äôs visit, Jos√© Ra√∫l Mulino said he had made an ‚Äúimportant‚Äù decision to pull out of China‚Äôs Belt and Road Initiative.

Ricardo Lombana, the leader of Panama‚Äôs opposition, called it an "invasion".

Javier Mart√≠nez-Acha, Panama‚Äôs foreign affairs minister, insisted the deal ‚Äúdoes not imply a surrender of sovereignty, nor does it violate the national constitution, nor the neutrality treaty‚Äù.

Trump demanded both US military and commercial ships be given free passage through the Panama and Suez canals.

Jorge Quijano, the former administrator of the Panama Canal Authority, was surprised by Trump‚Äôs allegations.

Sebastian King, special adviser for the union of marine engineers, believes the US allowed China to win infrastructure projects.

title: Beijing courts Latin America
content: LATIN American leaders and officials were welcomed to Beijing as the country seeks to draw the region closer in response to the trade war with the United States.
resumen:
LATIN American leaders and officials were welcomed to Beijing as the country seeks to draw the region closer in response to the trade war with the United States.

Beijing has stepped up economic and political cooperation with Latin American nations in recent years and has urged a united front against US President Donald Trump‚Äôs maelstrom of tariffs.

Two-thirds of Latin American countries have joined Beijing‚Äôs trillion-dollar Belt and Road (BRI) infrastructure programme, and China has surpassed the United States as the biggest trading partner of Brazil, Peru and Chile, among others.

The forum between China and the 33-member Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (Celac) is due to begin today.

A notable attendee is Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who arrived in Beijing on Saturday for a five-day state visit.

Brazilian exports to China reached over US$94bil last year, according to the United Nations Comtrade Database.

The South American agricultural power sends mainly soybeans and other primary commodities to China, while the Asian giant sells semiconductors, telephones, vehicles and medicines to Brazil.

Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi yesterday hosted his Cuban counterpart Bruno Rodriguez Parrilla, Venezuela‚Äôs Yvan Gil, Peru‚Äôs Elmer Schialer and Uruguay‚Äôs Mario Lubetkin for talks at Beijing‚Äôs ornate Diaoyutai State Guesthouse.

Others expected participants in the forum include Colombian President Gustavo Petro and Chilean President Gabriel Boric.

Petro said last week that he would sign a ‚Äúletter of intent‚Äù to join the BRI when he meets Chinese President Xi Jinping.

Xi will address the summit at its opening ceremony, according to Beijing‚Äôs foreign ministry.

Senior ministry official Miao Deyu said on Sunday that Beijing had ‚Äúalways approached the development of China-Latin America relations from a strategic and long-term perspective‚Äù.

China was ‚Äúwilling to strengthen communication and coordination with Latin American countries‚Äù in the face of US tariffs, and ‚Äújointly work to... oppose unilateralism and economic bullying‚Äù, Miao said.

title: US Cuts China Tariff to 30% in 90-Day Reprieve ‚Äì Highlights from US-China Trade Talks
content: New agreement sees reciprocal US-China tariffs drop from 125% to 10% for 90 days, with final US tariff rate on China lowered to 30% ...
resumen: On Monday, May 12, 2025, the White House and China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) released a joint statement in which they committed to lowering reciprocal tariff rates from 125 percent to just 10 percent for a period of 90 days. The existing 20 percent tariff on Chinese goods appears to remain in place, meaning the final tariff rate on Chinese goods will be 30 percent. The agreement follows a meeting between Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng, the US Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent, and US Trade Representative Ambassador Jamieson Greer, in Geneva over the weekend. In a statement released on Sunday, Bessent said that the two sides had made ‚Äúsubstantial progress [‚Ä¶] in the very important trade talks‚Äù, while a MOFCOM spokesperson on Monday called the agreement ‚Äúan important step for the two sides to resolve differences through equal dialogue and consultation‚Äù. In addition to lowering the duties, China has agreed to suspend or remove other non-tariff countermeasures it has taken against the US since the reciprocal tariffs were first imposed on April 2, 2025. Key Highlights from the Joint Statement on the US-China Economic and Trade Meeting in Geneva: China and the US to lower reciprocal tariff rates to 10% for 90 days by May 14. US‚Äôs final baseline tariff rate on Chinese goods to be 30%. China to suspend or remove ‚Äúnon-tariff countermeasures‚Äù taken against the US. Mechanism to continue bilateral discussions on economic and trade relations to be established. The headline agreement mentioned in the joint statement is the reduction of the two-way reciprocal tariffs from 125 percent to just 10 percent by May 14. The 10 percent ad valorem tariff is the ‚Äúminimum baseline tariff‚Äù that the US has implemented on all trade partners since April 2. After the US imposed a 34 percent ‚Äúreciprocal tariff‚Äù on China on April 2, China retaliated with a matching tariff on US goods. On April 9, Trump escalated the standoff by increasing the tariff again, with the two-way rate eventually peaking at 125 percent amid a series of tit-for-tat moves. In the new agreement, the US and China have agreed to entirely cancel the higher reciprocal tariff rates imposed in succession from April 9. The 34 percent rate initially imposed by the US on April 2 and by China on April 4 has been amended to 10 percent for an initial period of 90 days. Note that while the reciprocal tariff rate on Chinese goods was 125 percent, the final baseline tariff rate was 145 percent, as this duty was levied in addition to the 20 percent tariff rate that the US imposed on China earlier in the year. If the 34 percent reciprocal tariff rate is reinstated, the tariff on China would return to 54 percent. In addition to lowering the tariffs, China has agreed to ‚Äúadopt all necessary administrative measures to suspend or remove the non-tariff countermeasures taken against the United States since April 2, 2025‚Äù. On April 4, MOFCOM and China‚Äôs Customs Administration restricted the export of seven different types of rare earths, including various derivations of samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium, and yttrium. On the same day, MOFCOM also placed 16 American companies on the ‚Äúexport control list‚Äù and 11 American companies on the ‚Äúunreliable entities list‚Äù. A further 12 American companies were placed on the export control list and six on the unreliable entities list on April 9. Also on April 4, China‚Äôs State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) announced an investigation into DuPont China Group Co., Ltd., the Chinese subsidiary of the American chemicals giant DuPont, for suspected violations of China‚Äôs Anti-Monopoly Law. The joint statement makes no mention of the 20 percent tariff rate that Trump imposed on China in two rounds in February and March. This suggests that these duties remain in place. In a press briefing on Monday, Greer confirmed as much, saying that fentanyl was ‚Äúon its own track‚Äù and that the ‚Äúissue remains unchanged for now‚Äù. This means that the final tariff rate on Chinese goods entering the US will be 30 percent, not 10 percent. Additionally, China has not agreed to lift the tariffs it placed on some US goods in retaliation for the two rounds of tariffs that the US imposed in February and March. These tariffs are: A 15 percent tariff on coal and liquefied natural gas; A 10 percent tariff on crude oil, agricultural machinery, large-displacement cars, and pickup trucks; A 15 percent tariff on US chicken, wheat, corn, and cotton; and A 10 percent tariff on sorghum, soybeans, pork, beef, aquatic products, fruits, vegetables, and dairy products. Before April, China also took a series of non-tariff measures in response to the tariffs on Chinese goods. These include export controls on rare earth metals, the addition of US companies to the unreliable entities list, and an antitrust probe into Google. The joint statement also makes no mention of the reinstatement of the de minimis exemption, a rule that allows packages valued under US$800 to enter the US without customs duties or inspections. On April 2, Trump signed an executive order ending the de minimis exemption for parcels originating from the Chinese mainland and Hong Kong. The current agreement also does not address the fees implemented on Chinese vessels docking at US ports announced by the US Trade Representative (USTR) on April 17. Other tariffs, both universal and those specifically targeting China, such as the 25 percent steel and aluminum tariffs, the 25 percent auto tariffs, and the Biden-era tariffs on solar cells, semiconductors, and other tech-focused products, also remain in place. In the joint statement, China and the US committed to establishing ‚Äúa mechanism to continue discussions about economic and trade relations.‚Äù This mechanism will be represented by Vice Premier He on the Chinese side, and Representative Greer and Secretary Bessent on the US side. Following the meetings, Greer reiterated this issue: ‚ÄúJust remember why we‚Äôre here in the first place ‚Äî the United States has a massive $1.2 trillion trade deficit.‚Äù He added that the US is ‚Äúconfident‚Äù that the agreement reached between China and the US ‚Äúwill help us to work toward resolving that national emergency.‚Äù Under Trump‚Äôs previous term in office, China and the US reached a trade deal in early 2020, which saw China commit to purchasing a minimum of US$200 billion worth of additional US goods and services over a period of two years, including manufactured goods, agricultural goods, energy goods, and services.

title: Family farms depend on trade. We need Trump to make deals. | Opinion
content: The tariff situation today under President Trump is messy, charged with challenge and opportunity for farmers.
resumen: The author, Brian Reisinger, argues that family farms depend on trade and that the U.S. needs to negotiate new trade deals. He recalls the last time tariffs became a major issue, around 2015, when Trump promised to stop the world from "ripping off America." Farms were already facing challenges due to rising production and leveling demand. In 2018, Trump imposed tariffs on China and other countries. While economists acknowledged China's unfair practices, farmers initially accepted the short-term pain of foreign retaliation for better trade deals. The administration provided $28 billion in aid to farmers affected by falling sales. Trade eventually returned to normal, except with China. The author's sister, Malia, is the fourth generation in their family farm. She believes in drawing a hard line on unfair trade and being self-sufficient but also recognizes the need to sell American goods abroad. She believes a good trade deal benefits American farmers. The author suggests negotiating with one country at a time on one product at a time, diversifying trade, and avoiding trade-offs of large deals. The author, Brian Reisinger, is a writer who grew up on a family farm in Sauk County, Wisconsin. He contributes columns and videos for the Ideas Lab at the Journal Sentinel. He is the author of "Land Rich, Cash Poor: My Family‚Äôs Hope and the Untold History of the Disappearing American Farmer." Reisinger works in public affairs consulting for Wisconsin-based Platform Communications.

The CBOE Volatility Index, Wall Street‚Äôs fear gauge, sank more than 15% to its lowest level since the end of March. Tech stocks were particular winners on Monday: Apple (AAPL) gained 6.3%, Tesla (TSLA) rose 6.75%, Nvidia (NVDA) was up 5.4%, Amazon (AMZN) rose 8.1% and Intel (INTC) was up 3.55%. Automakers also surged: Jeep and Chrysler maker Stellantis (STLA) was up 6.5%, General Motors (GM) rose 4.4% and Ford (F) was up 2.6%. Bessent on Monday morning characterized the trade war de-escalation that he helped negotiate this weekend with his Chinese counterparts. Bessent told CNBC from Geneva. Bessent noted that America was negotiating from a position of strength because China needs the United States to buy its products more than the US relies on China for its goods exports. Bessent said the deal didn‚Äôt represent a major policy shift. The April 2 tariff level for China was 34%, so we have moved that down from 34% to 10%. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer spoke to the media in Geneva. As the next step in negotiating, the US will focus on expanding its supply chains for what Bessent called ‚Äústrategic necessities,‚Äù reducing its reliance on China for things like critical medicines, semiconductor chips and steel. Kevin Hassett, Director of the National Economic Council of the United States, told CNN‚Äôs Kate Bolduan Monday. Hassett said Trump had scored major concessions from China and the United Kingdom in their respective recent frameworks for trade negotiations.

title: Tariff Truce With China Demonstrates the Limits of Trump‚Äôs Aggression
content: President Trump‚Äôs triple-digit tariffs on Chinese products disrupted global trade ‚Äî but haven‚Äôt appeared to result in major concessions from Beijing.
resumen:
President Trump's decision to impose, and then walk back, triple-digit tariffs on Chinese products demonstrated the power and global reach of U.S. trade policy, but also illustrated the limitations of Mr. Trump‚Äôs aggressive approach.

The tariffs on Chinese goods, which the United States ratcheted up to a minimum of 145 percent in early April, brought much trade between the countries to a standstill. They caused companies to reroute business globally, importing less from China and more from other countries like Vietnam and Mexico. They forced Chinese factories to shutter, and brought some American importers to the verge of bankruptcy.

Within weeks, Trump officials were saying that the tariffs the president had chosen to impose on one of America‚Äôs largest trading partners were unsustainable, and that they were angling to reduce them.

Trade talks between the world‚Äôs largest economies in Geneva this weekend concluded with an agreement to reduce stiff levies on each other‚Äôs products by more than many analysts had anticipated. Chinese imports will face a minimum tax of 30 percent, down from 145 percent. China will lower its import duty on American goods to 10 percent from 125 percent. The two countries also agreed to hold talks to stabilize the relationship.

The talks this weekend, and the tariff chaos of the past month, did not appear to generate any other immediate concessions from the Chinese other than a commitment to keep talking.

Scott Kennedy, a China expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said the Geneva agreement represents an almost complete U.S. retreat that vindicates Xi‚Äôs decision to forcefully retaliate.

Mr. Trump and his advisers contend that the United States holds the strongest cards in trade negotiations.

Through his so-called reciprocal tariffs and maximalist levies on China, the ‚ÄúArt of the Deal‚Äù president is employing a strategy that involves manufacturing trade crises in hopes of extracting quick economic concessions. But when confronting an economic power with similar might and perhaps more willingness to endure pain, Mr. Trump opted to stand down, declaring China‚Äôs agreement to join him at the negotiating table a win.

Officials essentially said they had determined that they did not want ‚Äî or intend ‚Äî to go down the path that the president‚Äôs tariffs had set the United States on, of fully decoupling its economy from China.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said at a news conference in Geneva, ‚ÄúWe concluded that we have a shared interest. The consensus from both delegations is that neither side wanted a decoupling.‚Äù

Mr. Bessent said on the Fox Business Network last month, ‚ÄúThey have the most imbalanced economy in the history of the modern world. And I can tell you that this escalation is a loser for them.‚Äù

The tariffs proved painful for China, but they were also disruptive for the U.S. economy. American companies had started to warn of coming pain for consumers in the form of higher prices and less availability of products.

U.S. manufacturers were particularly concerned about China‚Äôs export restrictions on vital minerals and magnets. And while shipments from China to the United States plunged 21 percent in April from a year earlier, its exports to Southeast Asian countries surged 21 percent.

The decision to temporarily lower tariffs on China provides a welcome reprieve for businesses, but it will also do little to ease longer-run uncertainty that is weighing on U.S. firms. The two governments now have until mid-August to make progress toward a trade deal.

On Monday morning, Mr. Trump said that if the countries did not reach an agreement in that time, tariffs on Chinese products would rise again to be ‚Äúsubstantially higher,‚Äù though not to 145 percent.

‚ÄúAt 145, you‚Äôre really decoupling because nobody‚Äôs going to buy,‚Äù he added.

Matthew Shay, the chief executive of the National Retail Federation, which represents large and small retailers, called the temporary pause ‚Äúa critical first step to provide some short-term relief for retailers and other businesses that are in the midst of ordering merchandise for the winter holiday season.‚Äù

Gene Seroka, the executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, said on Monday that the 30 percent tariff that remained on China was still substantial, and that the enthusiasm of American consumers and the companies that relied on their shopping habits had been damaged by the threat of tariffs. Ninety days is also a relatively brief time frame for companies to try to restart stopped shipments from China.

Wendy Cutler, the vice president of the Asia Society Policy Institute, said three months was ‚Äúan extremely short amount of time to address the range of contentious trade matters that remain between the U.S. and China, including dealing with excess manufacturing capacity, excessive subsidization of Chinese firms and transshipment efforts by Chinese companies.‚Äù

Mr. Trump has said talks would be focused in part on ‚Äúopening up‚Äù China to American businesses. Officials said they had agreed to set up a regular cadence of talks with China, and suggested that some of those could center on Chinese purchases of U.S. products that would help to balance trade.

Chinese officials also agreed to significant purchases in a 2020 trade deal signed with Mr. Trump that were meant to help balance trade between the countries, but they ultimately did not fulfill them.

In an interview on CNBC on Monday, Mr. Bessent said the 2020 deal could serve as a ‚Äústarting point‚Äù for future talks and blamed the Biden administration for failing to enforce the agreement.

During his confirmation hearing, Mr. Bessent said he intended to push China to honor its commitments to purchase more American farm products.

Michael Pillsbury, who was a top China adviser to Mr. Trump in his first term, said, ‚ÄúEveryone thought in advance that the most important thing is to get Chinese adherence to the 2020 Phase 1 agreement that for many issues provides a foundation for going forward.‚Äù

Myron Brilliant, a senior counselor at DGA-Albright Stonebridge Group who advises clients on China, said, ‚ÄúThe two governments have given themselves a window to get something done on fentanyl and purchases. But what else will China agree to remains a big question going forward, given our longstanding persistent concerns over their trade policies.‚Äù

title: How major global and economic sectors are reacting to U.S. tariff policy
content: Tariffs remain top of mind for many across the economic landscape. The effects have been felt by the building industries in terms of increased costs, disrupted supply chains and economic uncertainty.
resumen:
Tariffs remain top of mind for many across the economic landscape. The effects have been felt by building industries in terms of increased costs, disrupted supply chains and economic uncertainty.

Last week‚Äôs webinar, ‚ÄúTrump's Tariffs: Transition or Turmoil?‚Äù hosted by Politico and welcoming journalists from across the globe focused on the near-term effects of tariffs, how trade environments have shifted in response, and what the next steps of the Trump Administration might be.

Details of U.S./Canada trade likely to be decided in USMCA renegotiation. Ari Hawkins, a Politico trade reporter, says that the recent meeting between newly-elected Prime Minister Mark Carney and President Donald Trump represents a potential ‚Äúeasing of tension.‚Äù While Trump has repeated his ‚Äú51st state‚Äù rhetoric, and Carney stated in the introductory meeting that ‚ÄúCanada is not for sale,‚Äù Hawkins still finds the administration‚Äôs treatment of Carney to be more favorable when compared with former Prime Minister Trudeau. ‚ÄúFor Carney himself, the Trump administration and Trump himself has taken a much calmer tone. It's been more conciliatory that was the goal of this meeting to level set to make sure that they had a path forward for negotiations, and in that sense, both sides did what they needed to do,‚Äù he says.

In terms of moving forward on a substantive trade agreement, Nick Taylor-Vaisey, Politico‚Äôs Ottawa bureau chief, noted that Trump has underscored that the USCMCA is a ‚Äúgood deal for everybody,‚Äù and offered a basic timeline of a review in 2026 or ‚Äúwithin the next year.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo maybe he's open to starting those talks earlier, which a lot of Canadian officials want, but we're waiting for details there,‚Äù Taylor-Vaisey says. Hawkins agreed that the administration is likely looking to the USMCA renegotiations to ‚Äúreally get into the weeds of a lot of these tariff disputes" with Canada.

Section 232 tariffs likely to remain and expand. In February, the Trump administration restored 25% tariffs on steel and increased the tariff on aluminum to 25% as well, both actions based on Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962. The administration also removed exemptions from previous tariffs on these materials. Hawkins says that further Section 232 investigations could lead to new tariffs in the coming months on a range of products, including semiconductors, lumber and critical minerals.

While the administration might make exemptions on materials like lumber before those investigations are completed, Hawkins says, they are still likely to face the Section 232 tariffs as part of the administration‚Äôs focus on incentivizing manufacturing and development within the U.S. Taylor-Vaisey says that given it‚Äôs a time of ‚Äúflux‚Äù for Canada, it‚Äôs hard to say what Canada might do with its lumber in terms of new trade agreements.

Unlike the tariffs levied on the basis of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, the Section 232 tariffs are legally tested, says Hawkins, and levied through the Department of Commerce. ‚ÄúIt's been legally tested, meaning that it could be more difficult for a judge to overturn that, even though it would still be on the basis of a national emergency,‚Äù he says.

title: With No Real Policy, Trump Asks Drugmakers to Lower U.S. Prices
content: The president has long complained that the United States pays more for medicines than other wealthy countries. But he offered no clear legal authority to mandate lower prices.
resumen:
On Monday, President Trump signed an executive order asking drugmakers to voluntarily reduce the prices of key medicines in the United States. The order cites no obvious legal authority to mandate lower prices. The order said the administration would consider taking regulatory actions or importing drugs from other countries in the future if drugmakers do not comply.

Last week, Mr. Trump hyped a coming announcement that was ‚Äúas big as it gets.‚Äù On Sunday evening, he teed up the order in a Truth Social post, writing that he would link U.S. drug prices to those in peer countries under a ‚Äúmost favored nation‚Äù pricing model. His executive order on Monday does not do that. Pharmaceutical stocks rose Monday on the news.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs executive order came just hours after House Republicans offered an expansive set of health care policy changes that would cut around $700 billion from Medicaid and the Obamacare marketplaces over a decade and would cause an estimated 8.6 million Americans to become uninsured. Congress declined to include any provisions to directly limit drug prices in that package.

The executive order also called on federal agencies to investigate why European countries get lower prices and to push them to pay more. The Trump administration has limited leverage to drive up prices in Europe.

Mr. Trump said on Monday before signing the order, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really more knocking the countries than the drug companies.‚Äù

With his executive order, Mr. Trump opted not to propose measures that could have had more teeth, such as calling for his administration to work with Congress on legislation or writing regulations to change how government health programs pay for some drugs.

Ameet Sarpatwari, who studies pharmaceutical policy at Harvard Medical School, said, ‚ÄúThe executive order reads more like an aspirational statement than a serious attempt to initiate a policy change.‚Äù

Mr. Trump has long railed against the current system, in which pharmaceutical companies charge the United States significantly higher prices than the rest of the world.

Mr. Trump threatened to use trade policy to push European countries to pay more for prescription drugs.

In his first term, Mr. Trump tried unsuccessfully to enact a more substantive policy to reduce some drug prices paid by Medicare. That plan would have applied only to 50 drugs, administered at clinics and hospitals. A federal court blocked it.

The White House had teased the announcement as seismic. Monday‚Äôs executive order, on its face, calls for much broader changes than Mr. Trump proposed in his first term, affecting more drugs and all Americans, not just some Medicare patients. But it lacks a clear mechanism for enacting the price reductions.

Stacie Dusetzina, a health policy professor at Vanderbilt University who studies drug pricing, said, ‚ÄúIt almost sounds like: We‚Äôll just ask for lower prices and see how that goes.‚Äù Barring more substantive action, she said, ‚ÄúI would not anticipate drug prices to come down in the near future.‚Äù

The order said that if the initial actions did not make enough progress in lowering U.S. drug prices, the Trump administration may ‚Äúpropose a rulemaking plan to impose most-favored-nation pricing.‚Äù

Democrats have introduced numerous bills to bring American prices more in line with those of foreign peers, and legislation passed during the Biden administration allows Medicare to negotiate directly on the price of a limited set of drugs used in the program.

The drug industry has also been bracing for punishing tariffs on imported medicines, which Mr. Trump has vowed to impose soon.

Pharmaceutical investors were relieved that Mr. Trump did not propose the more substantive policy he had threatened. After dropping in premarket trading, pharmaceutical stocks rebounded when the details of Mr. Trump‚Äôs move became clear. Merck‚Äôs stock rose by 6 percent on Monday. Pfizer‚Äôs closed up by nearly 4 percent. An index of smaller biotechnology stocks was up 4 percent.

Analysts at the Wall Street bank Jefferies wrote in a note to investors, ‚ÄúBetter than feared.‚Äù TD Cowen analysts said, ‚ÄúMore bark than bite.‚Äù

Lobbying groups for drugmakers said the United States should not look to other countries for how much it pays for drugs.

The main industry group, PhRMA, also applauded Mr. Trump for threatening to use trade negotiations to push foreign governments ‚Äúto pay their fair share for medicines.‚Äù

Stephen J. Ubl, PhRMA‚Äôs chief executive, said, ‚ÄúU.S. patients should not foot the bill for global innovation.‚Äù

Brand-name drug prices in the United States are three times as high, on average, as those in peer nations.

In other wealthy countries, the government generally pays for prescription drugs for the entire population, negotiating substantial discounts from drugmakers. Many other nations do their own comparisons with prices in peer countries to help determine what they are willing to pay.

In the United States, the government has very little formal involvement in setting drug prices, other than the Biden-era program for a limited number of drugs in Medicare. The Trump administration is now overseeing that program.

This month, Senator Josh Hawley, a Republican from Missouri, and Senator Peter Welch, a Democrat from Vermont, introduced a bill that would limit drug prices in the United States to an average of the prices paid by a group of peer countries.

Mr. Welch said he agreed with Mr. Trump that Americans are overpaying and that international comparisons could help set fairer prices. But he thinks Congress needs to tackle the issue to ensure a durable policy.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs executive order gave his administration one month to tell drug companies the voluntary ‚Äúprice targets‚Äù for certain medicines. A White House official said that weight-loss medicines known as GLP-1s ‚Äî a class of popular drugs like Zepbound and Wegovy ‚Äî would likely be among them.

Mr. Trump complained in his news conference Monday that ‚Äúthe fat shot‚Äù costs much less in Europe than in the United States.

In most cases, Americans can get these drugs for $500 a month without using insurance. European pharmacies often charge a few hundred dollars less.

title: Trump's tariffs have launched global trade wars. Here's a timeline of how we got here
content: The U.S. economy has experienced whiplash from President Donald Trump‚Äôs back-and-forth tariff threats with China, Canada, Mexico and more since January 2025.
resumen:
*   **January 20:** Donald Trump is sworn into office and promises to "tariff and tax foreign countries to enrich our citizens." He reiterates plans to create the External Revenue Service.
*   **January 26:** Trump threatens 25 percent tariffs on all Colombia imports and other retaliatory measures after President Gustavo Petro rejects two U.S. military aircraft. Petro announces a retaliatory 25 percent increase in Colombian tariffs on U.S. goods, but Colombia later reverses its decision.
*   **February 1:** Trump signs an executive order to impose tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada, and China - 10 percent on all imports from China and 25 percent on imports from Mexico and Canada starting Feb. 4.
*   **February 3:** Trump agrees to a 30-day pause on his tariff threats against Mexico and Canada.
*   **February 4:** Trump's new 10 percent tariffs on all Chinese imports to the U.S. go into effect. China retaliates the same day.
*   **February 10:** Trump announces plans to hike steel and aluminum tariffs starting March 12.
*   **February 13:** Trump announces a plan for ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs.
*   **February 25:** Trump signs an executive order instructing the Commerce Department to consider whether a tariff on imported copper is needed to protect national security.
*   **March 1:** Trump signs an additional executive order instructing the Commerce Department to consider whether tariffs on lumber and timber are also needed to protect national security.
*   **March 4:** Trump‚Äôs 25 percent tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico go into effect, though he limits the levy to 10 percent on Canadian energy. He also doubles the tariff on all Chinese imports to 20 percent. Canada and Mexico promise retaliatory measures. China imposes tariffs of up to 15 percent on a wide array of key U.S. farm exports.
*   **March 5:** Trump grants a one-month exemption on his new tariffs impacting goods from Mexico and Canada for U.S. automakers.
*   **March 6:** Trump postpones 25 percent tariffs on many imports from Mexico and some imports from Canada for a month.
*   **March 10:** China's retaliatory 15 percent tariffs on key American farm products take effect.
*   **March 12:** Trump's new tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports go into effect. The European Union takes retaliatory trade action. Canada announces plans to impose more retaliatory tariffs.
*   **March 13:** Trump threatens a 200 percent tariff on European wine, Champagne and spirits.
*   **March 24:** Trump says he will place a 25 percent tariff on all imports from any country that buys oil or gas from Venezuela, in addition to imposing new tariffs on the South American country itself, starting April 2.
*   **March 26:** Trump says he is placing 25 percent tariffs on auto imports, starting April 3.
*   **April 2:** Trump announces his long-promised ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs, declaring a 10 percent baseline tax on imports across the board starting April 5, as well as higher rates for dozens of nations that run trade surpluses with the U.S. to take effect April 9.
*   **April 3:** Trump's previously-announced auto tariffs begin.
*   **April 4:** China announces plans to impose a 34 percent tariff on imports of all U.S. products beginning April 10, matching Trump's new "reciprocal‚Äù tariff on Chinese goods.
*   **April 5:** Trump's 10 percent minimum tariff on nearly all countries and territories takes effect.
*   **April 9:** Trump's higher ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù rates go into effect. His administration says it will suspend most of these higher rates for 90 days, while maintaining the recently-imposed 10 percent levy on nearly all global imports. Trump says he will now raise import taxes against China to 125 percent ‚Äúeffective immediately‚Äù and later clarifies that total tariffs against China are actually now 145 percent. China upped its retaliation prior to this announcement. EU member states vote to approve their own retaliatory levies on 20.9 billion euros ($23 billion) of U.S. goods. Canada's counter tariffs on auto imports take effect.
*   **April 10:** The EU puts its steel and aluminum tariff retaliation on hold for 90 days.
*   **April 11:** China says it will raise tariffs on U.S. goods from 84 percent to 125 percent, in response to Trump's heightened levies. The new rate is set to begin April 12. The Trump administration unveils that electronics, including smartphones and laptops, will be exempt from so-called ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs.
*   **April 14:** Trump says he might temporarily exempt the auto industry from tariffs. The Trump administration also launches investigations into imports of computer chips, chipmaking equipment and pharmaceuticals. The Commerce Department says it's withdrawing from a 2019 agreement that had suspended an antidumping investigation into fresh tomato imports from Mexico.
*   **April 29:** Trump signs executive orders to relax some of his 25 percent tariffs on automobiles and auto parts.
*   **May 3:** The latest round of Trump's auto tariffs takes effect.
*   **May 4:** Trump threatens a 100 percent tariff on foreign-made films.
*   **May 6:** The U.S. trade deficit soared to a record $140.5 billion in March. The U.S. government announced that top officials are set to meet with a high-level Chinese delegation over the weekend in Switzerland. U.S. tariffs against China are set at 145 percent and China tariffs on the U.S. at 125 percent.
*   **May 7:** The Federal Reserve left its key interest rate unchanged at 4.3 percent.
*   **May 3:** The United States and Britain announced a trade deal.
*   **May 12:** The United States and China agreed to roll back most of the tariffs each nation had imposed on the other and declared a 90-day truce in their trade war. The Trump administration said it would reduce the 145 percent duties it had imposed on imports from China to 30 percent, while China said it would cut its 125 percent tariffs on U.S. goods to 10 percent.

title: Dow soars as trade war with China partially paused
content: The Trump administration declared victory in a trade war with China Monday after a temporary economic ceasefire that sent the Dow leaping 1,100 points.
resumen: The Trump administration declared victory in a trade war with China Monday after a temporary economic ceasefire that sent the Dow leaping 1,100 points. According to Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent, the ‚Äúdeal‚Äù reached between Beijing and Washington will see tariffs temporarily reduced by both governments, leaving U.S. importers paying 30% dues on Chinese made goods while Chinese importers cough up an extra 10% on U.S. goods. The Treasury Secretary said at a press conference in Geneva, Switzerland, ‚ÄúWe have reached an agreement on a 90-day pause and substantially moved down the tariff levels ‚Äî both sides, on the reciprocal tariffs, will move their tariffs down 115%.‚Äù The stock markets responded with glee, and by the end of the day the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up about 2.8%, the S&P 500 by about 3%, and the Nasdaq Composite by around 4%. The tariffs had been set at 145% on most Chinese goods entering the U.S. and at 125% on U.S. goods headed into China. The first round of tariffs, ostensibly aimed at reducing the amount of fentanyl and fentanyl precursors illegally brought into the United States but manufactured in China, were established on Feb. 1 and March 3 and each added a 10% tax on U.S. imports from China. The Chinese government swiftly responded by imposing equally sized import duties on U.S. natural gas, coal, farm machinery, food, and some specific agricultural products. Trump‚Äôs April 2 ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù global tariff announcement added an additional 34% tax on top of the earlier 20%. After China responded on April 4 with broad-based 34% tariffs of their own, Trump announced on April 8 that the U.S. duty would jump by another 50% to 104%. The next day, China answered with an 84% duty on U.S. imports. A day after that Trump upped the U.S. imports tax once more, to 145%, and within days China again responded with their own larger levy, topping out at 125%. Bessent described the sky-high tariffs as a sort of ‚Äúembargo‚Äù and noted that ‚Äúneither side wants that. We do want trade.‚Äù Dropping import fees to 30% and 10%, according to the Chinese Commerce Ministry, ‚Äúaligns with the expectations of producers and consumers in both countries and serves the interests of both nations as well as the common interests of the world.‚Äù The ministry encouraged the Trump Administration to refrain from future use of ‚Äúthe erroneous practice of unilateral tariff hikes.‚Äù According to the White House, the 90-day pause on tariffs represents a ‚Äúhistoric trade win for the United States‚Äù and is a further example of the ‚Äúart of the deal‚Äù in action. According to Harvard economist Dani Rodrik, the agreement doesn‚Äôt solve any problems except those that Trump created. Brooke Thomson, the president and CEO of Bay State-based business group the Associated Industries of Massachusetts, said that the plan is a positive development but cautioned a 90-day pause isn‚Äôt enough to help restore falling business confidence. According to the Trump Administration‚Äôs U.S. Trade Representative, Ambassador Jamieson Greer, the economy will respond well to the negotiated ceasefire. While both Bessent and Greer were in Geneva negotiating on behalf of the U.S. to lower tariffs, Trump was back home defending his tariff policy as an economic winner. According to the U.S. President, the tariffs have meant that ‚ÄúTRILLIONS OF DOLLARS (and therefore, record numbers of JOBS!) HAVE BEEN POURING INTO THE USA. THIS IS BECAUSE OF MY TARIFF POLICY, and our great November 5th Election WIN!‚Äù. Monday‚Äôs announcement of a reduction in tariffs will apparently not impact import taxes on Chinese steel and aluminum nor will it reinstate the ‚Äúde minimis‚Äù tariff exemption on orders worth less than $800, which the Trump Administration nixed earlier this month. U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent took part in a press conference after two days of closed-door discussions on trade between the United States and China, in Geneva, Switzerland, Monday, May 12, 2025.

title: Consumers get a 3-month reprieve as U.S. and China agree to temporarily slash tariffs
content: GENEVA ‚Äî The United States and China have agreed to temporarily slash reciprocal tariffs in a deal that surpassed expectations as the world‚Äôs two biggest economies seek to end a damaging trade war ...
resumen: The United States and China have agreed to temporarily slash reciprocal tariffs. The U.S. will cut extra tariffs it imposed on Chinese imports in April this year to 30% from 145% and Chinese duties on U.S. imports will fall to 10% from 125%. The new measures are effective for 90 days. U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer attended a news conference after trade talks with China in Geneva, Switzerland, May 12, 2025. Dow futures surged Monday after the deal was announced. Wall Street cheered the development with futures for the S&P 500 jumping 3.1%, while futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.5%. Futures for the Nasdaq, home to the biggest U.S. technology companies, soared 3.9%. American microchip companies, including ON Semiconductor, Micron and Broadcom, were among the biggest gainers early Monday. ON Semiconductor, Micron and Broadcom all soared between 6% and 8%. Nvidia rose 4.8%. Travel companies also enjoyed big gains, with American, Delta and United Airlines all up around 7%. Retailers, including Amazon (up 7.8%) and Best Buy (jumped 10.4%), also benefited from the announced tariff pause. The tariff dispute had brought nearly $600 billion in two-way trade to a standstill. The Geneva meetings were the first face-to-face interactions between senior U.S. and Chinese economic officials since Trump returned to power. Bessent said the deal did not include sector-specific tariffs. Zhiwei Zhang, chief economist at Pinpoint Asset Management in Hong Kong, said, "This is better than I expected. I thought tariffs would be cut to somewhere around 50%." Trump had hiked the tariffs paid by U.S. importers for goods from China to 145% since taking office in January. China hit back by putting export curbs on some rare earth elements and raising tariffs on U.S. goods to 125%. Shares in European firms hit by the trade war rallied after the deal. Shipping company Maersk was the biggest gainer in Europe, up more than 12%. Shares in luxury firms LVMH and Gucci-owner Kering were up 7.4% and 6.7% respectively. Wall Street stock futures climbed as the talks boosted hopes a global recession might be averted. Trump said the two sides had negotiated ‚Äúa total reset... in a friendly, but constructive, manner.‚Äù Greer said conversations over curbing the deadly opioid fentanyl were ‚Äúvery constructive‚Äù though on a separate track. U.S. and Chinese officials met over two days at the Swiss U.N. ambassador‚Äôs gated villa overlooking Lake Geneva.

title: Trump's tariff truce with China brings some relief but uncertainty over what's next
content: President Donald Trump's agreement with China to temporarily slash tariffs for 90 days offered the world a bit of welcome relief.
resumen:
President Donald Trump‚Äôs agreement with China to temporarily slash tariffs for 90 days offered the world a bit of welcome relief. The Trump administration agreed after talks this weekend in Switzerland to pare back its 145% in tariffs charged on imports from China to 30%. The Chinese government chose to reduce its retaliatory import taxes on U.S. goods from 125% to 10% while the sides continue to negotiate. Trump declared the de-escalation of the trade war a victory, saying he would soon chat with Chinese President Xi Jinping about how to preserve the financial relationship between the world's two largest economies. The tariffs are now elevated from when Trump took office and the scramble to respond to the White House's mix of threats and olive branches might leave CEOs, investors and consumers uneasy and unwilling to take risks.

Most imports will be taxed at a minimum of roughly 10%. The 10% figure has been Trump's baseline. He gave it to most countries for a 90-day negotiating period after his April 2 ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù tariff rollout. He kept the 10% rate as part of the framework with the United Kingdom announced last week. Trump's new 30% tariff on Chinese goods includes 20% tied to China's role in fentanyl and the 10% baseline applied elsewhere. Trump said on Friday, ‚ÄúWe have many deals coming down the line, but we always have a baseline of 10%.‚Äù Sectoral tariffs of 25% on autos, steel and aluminum are still in place, with Trump stressing that pharmaceutical drugs will also soon face import taxes. Trump said Monday that he told House Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader John Thune to include tariff revenues when looking at how to pay for their planned income tax cuts.

Taisu Zhang, a law professor who studies comparative legal and economic history at Yale University, said the chaos from last month probably was not for nothing. Both countries were testing their strengths, with Trump stressing the importance that foreign companies placed on accessing U.S. consumers and China emphasizing its resilience to an external shock. Zhang said, ‚ÄúAs recently as February, both sides probably harbored unrealistic assumptions about each other‚Äôs economic or political weaknesses or intents. The Americans had an exaggerated sense of their own bargaining power to begin with, and the Chinese may have had an exaggerated sense of their security from American economic pressure.‚Äù Zhang said, ‚ÄúThe best thing to come out of this agreement, therefore, seems to be a stronger sense of reality on both sides.‚Äù In that, Zhang said, it looks like the goals of the two countries align, with China consuming more and the U.S. manufacturing more.

The S&P 500 stock index jumped 3.3% in Monday trading.

If Trump's 145% tariffs caused fewer boats to leave for U.S. ports, the prospect of a slightly lower tariff rate might cause a stampede of shipping containers to flow across the ocean from China. Michael Starr, vice president of growth at the logistics company Zencargo, said, ‚ÄúThey can now start shipping for the holiday season. They‚Äôre going to rush as many orders out in these 90 days as possible. And yes, the vessels cannot come back as quickly into service as the freight can.‚Äù

University of Michigan economist Justin Wolfers stressed that many people would see the 90-day talks as a short-term positive because ‚Äúmoving tariffs from prohibitive and insane to merely very high is good news.‚Äù

Kevin Rinz, a senior fellow at the Washington Center for Equitable Growth, said, ‚ÄúMaybe some of those could live with 30%, at least for a while, but in 90 days, what are tariffs with China going to be? Will they go up or down from 30%? If up, how far? I have no idea, and if I were a firm that relies on imports from China, that would cause paralysis.‚Äù Rinz, who worked as an economist in the Obama and Biden administrations, tried to model the impact of the labor market based on Trump's own premise that any short-term pain from tariffs would eventually result in long-term gains. His analysis found a drop in hiring. Rinz said, ‚ÄúIt turns out, that scenario looks a lot like a recession over the next few years.‚Äù

title: Are Trump‚Äôs Tariffs Trying to Solve a Problem That Doesn‚Äôt Exist?
content: Below is a transcript of an episode of ‚ÄúThe Opinions.‚Äù We recommend listening to it in its original form for the full effect. You can do so using the player above or on the NYT Audio App, Apple, ...
resumen:
Jason Furman, an economist and former advisor to President Barack Obama, believes trade is beneficial. David Leonhardt, director of the Times editorial board, interviewed Furman on "The Opinions" to discuss the benefits of trade for Americans and the world.

Furman defines the modern era of trade as beginning after World War II, with tariffs decreasing and trade increasing until around 2008, when it plateaued. He argues that trade has improved the lives of Americans, citing examples of everyday products made with components from various countries. He believes that lower-income households are disproportionately dependent on these products. Furman states that trade frees us up to have better jobs and is especially important to the most hard-pressed Americans.

Furman believes that trade is a secondary or tertiary factor in economic problems, and that it is more of a positive than a negative. He states that the best quarter-century was 1950 to 1975, followed by 2000 to 2025, and the worst was 1975 to 2000.

Furman acknowledges that trade with China may have cost jobs, but he believes the net effect on manufacturing jobs was roughly neutral over the last 25 years. He also states that trade has been enormously positive for much of the rest of the world, leading to a rapid decline in poverty since 1990.

Furman agrees that the relationship between trade and democratization is more ambiguous.

Furman believes that if you do the trade part without doing the other parts, you‚Äôre a lot better off. He would focus on preparing people educationally for jobs, connecting them to jobs through apprenticeship programs, and wage insurance for older workers.

Furman expects that the tariffs will mean higher inflation and higher unemployment in the short run. Over the longer run, he expects the U.S. import and export shares to be lower.

Furman would distinguish between China and the rest of the world. For the rest of the world, he believes in greater integration. With China, he agrees with the Biden administration's approach of focusing on national security concerns. He believes Democrats should focus on fixing problems within the United States.

title: US and China hail 'constructive' Geneva trade talks
content: The US and China end high-stakes trade talks on a positive note, with US officials touting a "deal" to reduce the US trade deficit while Chinese officials said the sides had reached an "important ...
resumen:
Geneva talks between China and the US have been hailed as "substantial progress" between the two nations.

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer touted the talks with China as a success.

Chinese officials said the sides had reached "important consensus" and agreed to launch another new economic dialogue forum.

Neither side released details after they wrapped up two days of talks on Sunday in Switzerland.

Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng said a joint statement would be released in Geneva on Monday.

Vice-Commerce Minister Li Chenggang said it would contain "good news for the world".

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer described "substantial progress" and also said details would be announced on Monday.

Neither side mentioned any agreement to cut US tariffs of 145 per cent on Chinese goods and China's 125 per cent tariffs on US goods.

Mr Greer and Mr Bessent took no questions from reporters.

Mr Greer described the Geneva meetings' conclusion as "a deal we struck with our Chinese partners" that would help reduce the $US1.2 trillion ($1.9 trillion) US global goods trade deficit.

The US trade chief called Mr He, Mr Li and Vice-Finance Minister Liao Min "tough negotiators".

Mr He, speaking to reporters at China's mission to the World Trade Organization, described the talks as "candid, in-depth and constructive" on issues of concern to both countries.

The meeting achieved substantial progress, and reached important consensus.

He also met with WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, who said she was "pleased with the positive outcome" of the talks and urged the two countries to build on momentum to mitigate trade tensions.

The US and China agreed to establish a new consultation mechanism for trade and economic issues, with relevant details to be finalised as soon as possible, Mr He added.

The meeting was the first face-to-face interaction between senior US and Chinese economic officials since Mr Trump took office and launched a global tariff blitz, declaring a national emergency over the US fentanyl crisis and imposing a 20 per cent tariff on Chinese goods in February.

Mr Trump followed with a 34 per cent "reciprocal" duty on Chinese imports in April, and subsequent rounds pushed the rates into triple digits, bringing nearly $US600 billion ($935 billion) in two-way trade to a standstill.

Mr Trump said on Friday that an 80 per cent tariff on Chinese goods "seems right", suggesting for the first time a specific reduction target.

Mr Greer said there was a lot of groundwork done before the Geneva meetings on Saturday and Sunday, and that the result would address the national emergency that Mr Trump declared over growing US trade deficits.

A White House press release that simply repeated Mr Bessent's and Mr Greer's brief comments with no details ran the headline: "US announces China trade deal in Geneva."

White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett said the Chinese were "very, very eager" to engage in discussions and rebalance trade relations with the US.

title: How President Donald Trump Could Support Working Class Voters
content: Lynn Forester de Rothschild argues that a pro-growth and pro-worker agenda is necessary to support working class Americans.
resumen:
President Donald Trump increased his support among voters without a college degree from around 50% in 2020 to 56% in 2024, with more than 50 million working class people voting for Donald Trump in 2024.

The author offers four recommendations for President Trump to more meaningfully demonstrate his commitment to the working people:

1.  Stop Collecting Tax from the Lowest Paid Workers: The United States begins to collect tax from working families starting at an annual income of only $21,900 for a head of household, even though the national poverty level for a family of four is $32,150. The Trump Administration should legislate so that there is a zero federal tax rate for families who earn less than the federal poverty level.
2.  Provide Workers the Skills they Need: Portable training accounts, which follow workers across jobs, would provide continuity in a dynamic economy. The author urges President Trump to invest in education and skills training.
3.  Give Workers an Investment Where they Work: By reforming current regulatory and litigation risks around Employee Stock Ownership Plans (ESOPs), the administration can unlock share ownership opportunities for workers‚Äînot only in private firms but also public companies.
4.  Embrace worker-centric AI: The World Economic Forum‚Äôs Future of Jobs Report highlights opportunities in sectors such as agriculture, food processing, nursing, and software development. The White House, with Vice President JD Vance‚Äôs experience in tech, should seize this moment to build a national AI strategy that does not leave the workers behind. More than 250 CEOs signed an open letter calling for computer science and AI to become graduation requirements nationwide across the US. They highlight research showing a single AI course raises wages 8% across all students. The letter argues universal AI could unlock $660 billion in annual economic value and notes only 12 states currently mandate the subject.

title: From US dollar hegemony to opportunity for euro
content: While internationalisation does carry risks, the eurozone is well-positioned to mitigate them. For example, the eurozone‚Äôs macro-prudential policy frameworks, which are much stronger than those in the ...
resumen: International monetary and financial systems may not be immutable. The upheaval spurred by US President Donald Trump‚Äôs trade and tariff war is remarkable and difficult to decipher. Charles P. Kindleberger‚Äôs theory of hegemonic stability states that an open and stable international system depends on a dominant world power. In the nineteenth century, that power was Great Britain. World War I took its toll on Britain, which by the 1930s no longer had sufficient resources to underpin the international monetary system. The United States was an ascending power but was not yet ready to fill Britain‚Äôs shoes. This ‚ÄúKindleberger gap‚Äù coincided with the Great Depression and the escalating political turmoil that culminated in World War II. In 1944, delegates from 44 countries met in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, where they orchestrated a smooth transition between the old and the new hegemons. The United States accounted for 35% of world gross domestic product (GDP) at the time. The US dollar has retained its dominance as a reserve asset, invoicing currency, and anchor for fixed exchange rates. The US Federal Reserve‚Äôs policy decisions and the US economy‚Äôs performance still shape the global financial cycle. We seem to be approaching a new ‚ÄúKindleberger gap‚Äù. The existing hegemon appears to be self-destructing, as it refuses to supply global public goods, and there is no clear candidate to fill its shoes. The European Union (EU) is not prepared to take up the mantle, and China is not even integrated into global financial markets. The Trump administration appears convinced that global demand for US dollar assets is a burden. If a currency is to serve an international role, the country issuing it generally needs to enjoy economic pre-eminence and occupy a central position in global trade. These qualities depend on innovative capabilities and growth potential, with military power and geopolitical alliances also playing a role. None of this is possible without an open economy and high-quality, stable institutions. The United States under Trump is rapidly eroding trust in the US dollar. In early April, Trump announced ultra-high tariffs on goods from dozens of countries running bilateral trade surpluses. US Treasury yields rose, the US stock market fell, and the US dollar depreciated. This economic and financial distress creates an opportunity for the eurozone to capture some of the exorbitant privilege long enjoyed by the United States. This includes cheaper capital for eurozone governments and businesses, which could support fiscal sustainability, and easier refinancing during times of crises. It also includes increased geopolitical clout. The eurozone is well-positioned to mitigate risks. The eurozone‚Äôs macro-prudential policy frameworks are much stronger than those in the United States. The eurozone must deepen its single market in goods and services and strengthen its trade relationships. Europe could consider starting to invoice climate-friendly products in euros. The eurozone should also commit to completing the banking union and the savings and investment union. Efforts should be made to deliver a true eurozone-wide safe asset. Joint debt issuance for emergency defence spending could be a good starting point. The bloc must increase the sovereignty of its own payments systems. This would probably rely on a central bank digital currency, complemented with a robust payment system. The European Central Bank‚Äôs function as lender of last resort must be carefully structured.

title: Asia Stocks Rise on Hope for Lower Tariffs After U.S.-China Talks
content: Investors were optimistic after American officials touted progress in trade negotiations over the weekend, though details had yet to be released.
resumen:
Stocks surged around the world after U.S. and Chinese officials said they agreed to temporarily suspend most of the tariffs they have imposed on each other.

Futures for the S&P 500 suggested that U.S. stocks would open nearly 3 percent higher when trading begins in New York on Monday morning. Futures for the tech-heavy Nasdaq climbed nearly 4 percent.

The S&P 500 dropped almost 20 percent below its peak in February, but it has since rebounded, recovering roughly two-thirds of its losses as various exemptions and pauses to U.S. tariffs have been announced.

In a joint statement, released on Monday after weekend talks in Geneva, the United States and China said they had reached an agreement to reduce their respective tariffs for 90 days while trade negotiations continue.

The United States would reduce the tariff on Chinese imports to 30 percent from its current 145 percent, while China would lower its import duty on American goods to 10 percent from 125 percent.

After the statement‚Äôs release, the U.S. dollar strengthened against a wide range of currencies. U.S. Treasury yields also rose.

Hong Kong‚Äôs benchmark Hang Seng Index jumped about 3 percent, while the Stoxx Europe 600 index rose about 1 percent. Oil prices, which are sensitive to expectations of global economic growth, also rose, gaining more than 3 percent.

Over the weekend, Washington and Beijing held their first meetings since ratcheting up tit-for-tat trade barriers on each other, effectively blocking much of the trade between the countries.

After the trade conversations concluded, however, officials from both sides touted significant progress.

That was enough to edge stocks higher in Japan, South Korea and mainland China during the Asia trading day.

‚ÄúThe conflict between the United States and China over tariffs has passed a major hurdle,‚Äù said Takahide Kiuchi, executive economist at the Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo. The Trump administration is wary of tariffs dealing a major blow to the U.S. economy and therefore it is unlikely that levies will be raised higher than 100 percent again, he said.

The stocks most exposed to global trade flows surged on the news. For example, A.P. Moeller-Maersk and Hapag-Lloyd, two of the world‚Äôs largest shipping companies, jumped more than 10 percent.

Economists have warned that U.S.-China trade tensions significantly increased the possibility of an economic downturn.

The World Trade Organization has forecast that the continuing division of the global economy into ‚Äúrival blocs‚Äù could cut global gross domestic product by nearly 7 percent over the long run.

In April, the International Monetary Fund lowered its 2025 outlook for all Group of 7 nations, including Germany and Japan, the world‚Äôs third- and fourth-largest economies, due largely to U.S. tariffs.

Last week, China reported that its exports to the United States in April dropped 21 percent from a year earlier.

Beijing placed export restrictions on key minerals and magnets. China has been steadfast in saying it does not intend to make trade concessions in response to Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs. Nancy Vanden Houten, U.S. economist at Oxford Economics, wrote in a research note on Saturday. Ms. Vanden Houten explained that even if the United States reduced the tariff rate on Chinese imports to 80 percent, the overall effective tariff rate for imports would be three times higher than projections from when Mr. Trump was elected. Some analysts and executives have said that tariffs above 50 percent are generally high enough to prohibit trade. Mr. Trump appears poised to declare that any concessions made by China are a win for the United States. Mr. Trump declared: ‚ÄúGREAT PROGRESS MADE!!!‚Äù

title: Three good reasons why the US dollar has further to fall
content: The movement in the US dollar against the major currencies has gone into something of a holding pattern over recent weeks as the currency markets await fresh developments on the US‚Äôs trade war with ...
resumen:
Roger J Kerr outlines why the US dollar is still at risk to a further leg downwards from current levels.

Summary of key points:
- Currency markets pause USD selling ‚Äì however there is more to come!
- On the verge of a new US dollar cycle.
- NZ employment data defies the negative forecasts.

The movement in the US dollar against the major currencies has gone into something of a holding pattern over recent weeks as the currency markets await fresh developments on the US‚Äôs trade war with the rest of the world and also a clearer direction and messaging from the Federal Reserve as to when their next change will be with interest rates.

The US dollar will have a period of consolidation following the rapid collapse from 110.00 on the Dixy Index in January to lows of 98.00 last month. The USD Index has returned to 100.00 as the EUR/USD rate has corrected back from highs of $1.1550 to the $1.1200/$1.1300 area.

The pause in US dollar selling is also related to a view that perhaps the worst is behind us in terms of the impact of Trump‚Äôs tariff attack on the US and global economy. If progress is made by de-escalating the negative impact of tariffs on the US economy by negotiated trade deals and lower tariff levels finally agreed, the reasons for selling the US dollar over the last three months would be reduced.

As a consequence of the USD recovery and stabilisation, the NZD/USD exchange rate has not been able to push through higher above the 0.6000 barrier and has remained in its tight trading range between 0.5900 and 0.6000.

The Americans and Chinese have agreed to meet in Geneva this weekend to discuss tariffs and trade. The financial markets would be expecting far too much if they think that a deal to reduce tariffs to workable levels on both sides would be a result of this first meeting. These trade discussions are likely to go on for months.

Against the backdrop of more settled FX markets over recent weeks, there are still three good reasons why the US dollar is still at risk to a further leg downwards from current levels:

- Asian exporters selling out of USD cash surpluses: Asian exporting companies have hoarded massive US dollar cash reserves over the last decade. It has been reported that up to USD2.5 trillion is currently held in USD‚Äôs by Asian exporters and institutional investors. China, Taiwan, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam all run trade surpluses with the US and to date those surpluses have been held in USD. The Asian holders of USD cash reserves have a big incentive to sell before the USD depreciates any further.
- Global fund manager‚Äôs reducing USD portfolio weights: Fund managers have been over-weight USD asset classes over the last five years. Australia‚Äôs Future Fund Chief Executive, Raphael Arndt has warned that ‚Äúthe Trump administration‚Äôs protectionist policies threaten the US dollar‚Äôs status as the dominant global currency and could force investors to reduce their holdings‚Äù. The Future Fund at USD240 billion in assets is ranked 17th largest in the world.
- The Federal Reserve‚Äôs next big decision: Chair Powell at the Fed meeting last week was adamant that he has the luxury of time to wait and see how the economic data emerges over coming months before making a decision to adjust interest rates downwards again. The uncertainty and risk around rising inflation and softening employment had escalated in the Fed‚Äôs view. The Fed also seem reluctant to recognise the forward-looking ‚Äúsoft‚Äù economic data such as deteriorating consumer and business confidence surveys. The Fed need to trust the soft forward-looking data and act sooner rather than later with interest rate cuts. When they realise the risk is greater with rising unemployment than permanent inflation, they should have sufficient evidence to cut interest rates at their 18th June meeting. Such a shift in the Fed‚Äôs stance would be negative for the US dollar.

All three of the above-described forces on the US dollar working in tandem at the same point in time, certainly increases the probability of another leg lower in the USD Dixy Index to 95.00 over coming weeks/months.

Over the last 55 years since 1970, the US dollar has posted three major up-cycles (1980-85, 1992-2000 and 2010-2024) and three major down-cycles (1970-1980, 1985-1992 and 2000-2010). Previous cyclical lows for USD in the 80.0 to 90.0 region were in 1978-1980, 1991-1995 and 2009-2012.

The stronger USD cycle from 2010 to 2025 has been much longer in duration than the other cycles because of US economic exceptionalism due to superior productivity gains from technological innovation. The new Trump regime‚Äôs policies to put up a protective wall around the US economy and to stop being a policeman to global conflicts, suggests that the period of US exceptionalism is coming to an end, and therefore the USD cyclical gains are also coming to an end.

To make US manufacturing competitive again (as Trump pines for), it is clear that simple product costing and pricing requires a lower US dollar value. Given the massive capital exodus from the US over recent months, the next cyclical downturn in USD may transform into a more structural weakening.

Consensus forecasts beforehand were for the New Zealand unemployment rate to increase from 5.10% in the December 2024 quarter to 5.30% in the March 2025 quarter. The result was an unchanged unemployment rate at 5.10%.

The growing evidence from the export boom taking place in regional New Zealand would point to an entirely different GDP growth trajectory for the NZ economy this year. The public sector right-sizing in Wellington and Auckland construction firms reducing worker‚Äôs hours is certainly negatively impacting the retail and residential property sectors in our two big cities. However, economic conditions in the provinces have certainly turned up sharply. Record high dairy, beef and lamb prices (despite tariff uncertainties) are driving increased spending and investment. Any nationwide business in New Zealand today will tell you that sales in Auckland and Wellington are down on budget, but the rest of the country is well ahead of budget. Higher export prices stimulate increased investment and production, which in turn require more labour. Outside of Auckland and Wellington, employment is growing, and it is only a matter of time before in transfers through into the property-dominated Auckland economy.

title: U.S. Farm economy is starting to see first hits from Trump tariffs
content: Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs are upending crop trading, delaying tractor purchases and constraining imports of chemical supplies into the U.S.
resumen:
Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs are upending crop trading, delaying tractor purchases and constraining imports of chemical supplies into the U.S.

The disruptions in global trade threaten to extend a years-long slump in the U.S. farm industry, which had already been struggling with ample supplies, depressed crop prices and rising competition from Brazil.

Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. and Bunge Global SA saw their combined operating profits slump by about $750 million in the first quarter.

Importers put off purchases of U.S. grain and oilseeds as Trump threatened tariffs as well as levies on any Chinese vessels docking at American ports.

Tractor makers CNH Industrial NV and AGCO Corp. also reported lower first-quarter sales.

Shipments of phosphate into the U.S. have trailed last year‚Äôs levels because vessels have been diverted to other countries to avoid the nation‚Äôs 10 per cent tariff, Mosaic Co. said in its earnings statement.

Nutrien Ltd. said its branded products could potentially cost as much as 7.5 per cent more, with even higher adjustments expected for generic ingredients.

Minerva SA said tariff turmoil drove increased Chinese demand and higher export prices for South American beef in the first quarter, helping lift profits for the Brazilian supplier.

China has effectively shut its market for U.S. meat exporters including Smithfield Foods Inc.

China has already shifted to Brazil for a meaningful part of its soybean needs since Trump first raised tariffs on goods from the Asian nation in 2018.
