title: Nevada truckers who backed Trump now grapple with trade war fallout
content: The dramatic escalation of Trump‚Äôs tariffs on Chinese imports ‚Äî with rates soaring to 145% on select goods ‚Äî creates significant hardship for Nevada‚Äôs trucking sector.
resumen: Steve Finn, owner of Premium Trucking in Las Vegas, voted for President Donald Trump in November. Finn supports Trump‚Äôs vision to revitalize domestic production through tariff-centered strategy, but he is critical of how these trade policies have been executed. The dramatic escalation of Trump‚Äôs tariffs on Chinese imports ‚Äî with rates soaring to 145% on select goods ‚Äî creates significant hardship for Nevada‚Äôs trucking sector. Many local operators depend on consistent freight contracts from the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach, which serve as the principal entry points for Chinese merchandise into American markets. The critical West Coast hubs experienced a striking 44% reduction in shipping traffic compared with the previous year‚Äôs figures. Finn says about one-third of his company‚Äôs business comes from the port of Los Angeles. He‚Äôs already seen a 20% drop in trucks transloaded from the port. Truline Corp. President Paul Truman operates a trucking company out of Las Vegas with a fleet of more than 300 trucks. The lag time between products arriving at the port docks and making their way to Las Vegas stores could ‚Äúbe as short as two weeks.‚Äù Shashi Nambisan, director of UNLV‚Äôs Transportation Research Center, said it takes three to four weeks for a Chinese product to get to a California port, and a few days to get it offloaded and on its way to Las Vegas. Gene Seroka, executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, said retailers have around three to five weeks of full inventory in the tank. Trump said in an interview with ABC News late last month, ‚Äúat 145 (percent), they basically can‚Äôt do much business with the United States.‚Äù His treasury secretary, Scott Bessent, has said the same, calling the tariffs a de facto embargo. Nambisan believes the Trump administration has moved far too quickly. It could take companies anywhere from a couple of months to a year to move their production out of China to a less-tariffed country. Moving production to the U.S.? That‚Äôs at least a year, if not a few, to get production running with a workforce that can operate it, Nambisan said. Paul Enos, CEO of the Nevada Trucking Association, is still hopeful. A CNBC poll of CEOs found a third expected to make job cuts this year due to tariffs. In another April poll, nearly two-thirds of CEOs said they expected a recession within the next six months. Finn said it was impossible to prepare for the slowdowns at the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach. Much of Finn‚Äôs business relies on conventions. The CES tech extravaganza each January sets the tone at the start of the year. Truman says he feels like he‚Äôs in a good position with growth last year and some new accounts to start 2025, but if the economy sours ‚Äî like multiple institutions in Nevada believe will happen ‚Äî ‚Äúit‚Äôs going to affect everybody.‚Äù Enos said he wasn‚Äôt worried about the trade war being prolonged. Data analysis firm CarrierOK reported that 88,000 trucking companies closed in 2023. Nambisan said a drop in shipping to Southern California‚Äôs ports would be proportional to its impact on Las Vegas‚Äô trucking companies; a 25% drop in inflows would mean a 25% drop in transport along Interstate 15 between the two metro areas. Finn said he wouldn‚Äôt pull the lever for Trump again if given the opportunity today. Enos, who also voted for Trump, hasn‚Äôt wavered in his support.

title: Trump‚Äôs trade deals may support the S&P 500, offering nervous investors an opportunity to sell
content: SINGAPORE] More than a month after US President Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù, he is giving the world a glimpse at what it will take to get him to relent on the hefty tariffs he has slapped on most ...
resumen:
A string of unfinished trade deals could give Trump a pretext to roll back tariffs if the economic pain becomes too much to bear.

The US and UK announced an ‚Äúeconomic prosperity deal‚Äù, which will see tariff-free beef exports between the US and UK, and the UK reduce its tariff on US ethanol to zero. The US will reduce its industry-specific tariffs on UK cars, steel and aluminium. The US will maintain its baseline reciprocal tariff of 10 per cent on most imports from the UK.

The US and China also began trade discussions over the weekend in Switzerland, with Trump floating the possibility of cutting US tariffs on Chinese goods if the talks are substantive.

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said last week that the US-China talks will initially focus on de-escalating the tensions between the two nations.

The US-UK Economic Prosperity Deal is still a work-in-progress that could take months or even years to complete.

If the US maintains its baseline reciprocal tariff of 10 per cent on its trading partners, it would represent long-term headwinds for global trade.

After tumbling more than 12 per cent over just four trading sessions following Liberation Day, the S&P 500 has regained almost all the ground it lost. The benchmark US stock index ended last week at 5,659.91 ‚Äì just 0.2 per cent below where it closed before the Liberation Day tariffs were announced.

The US dollar index (DXY) ended last week at 100.42 ‚Äì down about 3.3 per cent since Apr 2, and down 7.4 per cent since the beginning of this year.

For most trade-oriented economies in Asia, the tariffs would essentially amount to a major demand shock. For the US, the impact is likely to be a significant supply shock as well as a demand shock.

On Apr 30, the US Bureau of Economic Analysis said US gross domestic product in Q1 2025 shrank 0.3 per cent.

US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said last week that the import surge was likely to have been driven by businesses bringing in goods early to avoid the increased tariffs. Private domestic final purchases grew a solid 3 per cent in Q1 2025, the same as last year‚Äôs pace.

Powell also warned that Trump‚Äôs tariffs could put the Fed‚Äôs dual-mandate goals of maximum employment and stable prices in conflict. ‚ÄúIf the large increases in tariffs that have been announced are sustained, they are likely to generate a rise in inflation, a slowdown in economic growth and an increase in unemployment,‚Äù he noted.

The US central bank said last week that it would maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at between 4.25 and 4.5 per cent. Powell said this policy rate is ‚Äúin a good place‚Äù as the Fed awaits further clarity on the tariffs and their impact on the US economy. The median projection of participants at the March meeting was that there would be two 25-basis-point rate cuts in 2025.

Some companies ‚Äì including Ford, Mattel and UPS ‚Äì declined to provide any updated guidance in light of all the uncertainty.

With the S&P 500 now back at its pre-Liberation Day levels, I‚Äôm inclined to use the opportunity to lighten my exposure to the US market.

Asian investors have been pulling out of the US market in favour of Europe and China ‚Äì or simply cash and gold.

The S&P 500 is still trading at higher earnings multiples than the Stoxx Europe 600, the Nikkei 225 and the Hang Seng Index.

title: How much inventory did companies actually build ahead of tariffs?
content: To what degree does today‚Äôs economic activity reflect a pull forward of purchases that would‚Äôve occurred further down the road?
resumen:
**Main Content:**

*   A significant economic question is the degree to which current economic activity reflects a pull-forward of purchases due to anticipated tariffs.
*   Companies have been pulling forward purchases and stockpiling goods to mitigate the impact of future tariffs.
*   Quotes from Citigroup, UPS, Apple, Amazon, Kraft Heinz, and WD-40 indicate companies are accelerating imports and building inventory.
*   Deutsche Bank's Binky Chadha estimates excess imports over the last 3 months were about $190 billion, or around 3 weeks extra.
*   Companies typically maintain about 3 months of inventory, but have been raising that buffer, especially since the COVID pandemic.
*   Chadha estimates companies have about 1 to 2 months of buffer before tariff impacts start to bite.
*   BofA analysts express skepticism toward the idea that warehouses are well stocked, citing a surge in consumer goods imports in March, but also consumers buying ahead.
*   Goldman Sachs' David Kostin concludes that 1Q data do not show a buildup of inventories, with the S&P 500 inventory-to-sales ratio declining.
*   The March retail sales report showed an unusual spike in auto sales, supporting the idea of consumers pulling forward purchases.
*   The uncertainty around tariffs remains a significant issue.
*   The Federal Reserve left its target for the federal funds rate unchanged at a range of 4.25% to 4.5%.
*   Fed Chair Powell stated that sustained large increases in tariffs are likely to generate a rise in inflation, a slowdown in economic growth, and an increase in unemployment.

*   Initial claims for unemployment benefits fell to 228,000 during the week ending May 3, down from 241,000 the week prior.
*   Median inflation expectations were unchanged at the one-year-ahead horizon at 3.6% and increased by 0.2 percentage point at the three-year-ahead horizon to 3.2%.
*   Gas prices are ticking lower, with the national average at $3.15.
*   The Manheim Used Vehicle Value Index increased to 208.2, an increase of 4.9% from a year ago.
*   The Atlanta Fed‚Äôs wage growth tracker shows the median hourly pay in April was up 4.3% from the prior year.
*   Nonfarm business sector labor productivity decreased 0.8% in the first quarter of 2025.
*   The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was unchanged at 6.76%.
*   S&P Global‚Äôs May U.S. Services PMI indicates business activity and hiring have come closer to stalling in April.
*   The U.S. trade deficit widened to a record in March to $140.5 billion.
*   The New York Fed‚Äôs Global Supply Chain Pressure Index remains near historically normal levels.
*   Peak day office occupancy was 63.3% on Tuesday last week.
*   The Atlanta Fed‚Äôs GDPNow model sees real GDP growth rising at a 2.3% rate in Q2.
*   The tariffs announced by President Trump threaten to upend global trade.
*   Earnings look bullish, demand is positive, but growth is cooling.
*   Analysts expect the U.S. stock market could outperform the U.S. economy.
*   The long-term outlook for the stock market remains favorable.
*   Warren Buffett stated, "The long-term trend is up."

content: Sensitive talks between U.S. and Chinese delegations over tariffs that threaten to upend the global economy ended after a day of prolonged negotiations and will resume Sunday, an official told The ...
resumen:
Sensitive talks between U.S. and Chinese delegations over tariffs ended after a day of prolonged negotiations and will resume Sunday, an official told The Associated Press.

U.S. President Donald Trump posted on social media that a reset on trade between both countries was being discussed.

Trump wrote: ‚ÄúA very good meeting today with China, in Switzerland. Many things discussed, much agreed to. A total reset negotiated in a friendly, but constructive, manner. We want to see, for the good of both China and the U.S., an opening up of China to American business. GREAT PROGRESS MADE!!!‚Äù.

The meeting lasted over 10 hours and featured Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and a delegation led by Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng.

The official who spoke to the AP requested anonymity.

Several convoys of black vehicles left the residence of the Swiss ambassador to the U.N. in Geneva, which hosted the talks.

Saturday‚Äôs talks were held in the ‚ÄúVilla Saladin‚Äù overlooking Lake Geneva.

Trump last month raised U.S. tariffs on China to a combined 145%, and China retaliated by hitting American imports with a 125% levy.

Trump suggested Friday that the U.S. could lower its tariffs on China, saying in a Truth Social post that ‚Äú 80% Tariff seems right! Up to Scott.‚Ä≥.

Sun Yun, director of the China program at the Stimson Center, noted it will be the first time He and Bessent have talked.

Trump has aggressively used tariffs as his favorite economic weapon. He has imposed a 10% tax on imports from almost every country in the world.

His tariffs on China include a 20% charge meant to pressure Beijing into doing more to stop the flow of the synthetic opioid fentanyl into the United States. The remaining 125% involve a dispute that dates back to Trump‚Äôs first term.

During Trump‚Äôs first term, the U.S. alleged that China uses unfair tactics to give itself an edge in advanced technologies.

After nearly two years of negotiation, the United States and China reached a so-called Phase One agreement in January 2020.

Trump is also agitated by America‚Äôs massive trade deficit with China, which came to $263 billion last year.

Bessent and Greer also met with Swiss President Karin Keller-Sutter.

Trump last month suspended plans to slap hefty 31% tariffs on Swiss goods. For now, he has reduced those taxes to 10% but could raise them again.

The government in Bern is taking a cautious approach.

The government said Swiss exports to the United States on Saturday were subject to an additional 10% tariff, and another 21% beginning Wednesday.

The United States is Switzerland‚Äôs second-biggest trading partner after the EU.

U.S.-Swiss trade in goods and services has quadrupled over the last two decades.

Switzerland abolished all industrial tariffs on Jan. 1 last year, meaning that 99% of all goods from the United States can be imported into Switzerland duty-free.

title: A delicate balance as China comes to negotiating table
content: Since US president Donald Trump imposed steep tariffs on China last month, Beijing has responded in kind. On state and social media, it posted images of Mao Zedong, lambasted "imperialists", and sent ...
resumen: Since US president Donald Trump imposed steep tariffs on China last month, Beijing has responded in kind. Chinese officials have grown increasingly alarmed about tariffs' impact on the economy and the risk of isolation as China's trading partners have started negotiating deals with Washington. These factors, along with outreach by the US and an easing of Trump's rhetoric, persuaded Beijing to send its economic tsar He Lifeng for meetings with US counterparts in Switzerland this weekend. Re-engagement was complicated by the fractious nature of US-China diplomacy. Beijing considered a letter the US side sent to Chinese ministries in late April about fentanyl "arrogant". Efforts to arrange talks were further impaired by disagreements over which officials should be involved. China's foreign ministry said in a statement to Reuters that it reiterated that "China's firm opposition to the US abuse of tariffs is consistent and clear, and there is no change". China's Vice Foreign Minister Hua Chunying said on Friday that China has full confidence in its ability to manage US trade issues, adding that the Trump administration's approach cannot be sustained. The trade war between the world's two largest economies, combined with Trump's decision last month to impose duties on dozens of other countries, has disrupted supply chains, unsettled financial markets and stoked fears of a sharp downturn in global growth. Chinese export restrictions, meanwhile, have squeezed the supply of critical minerals the US needs for weapons, electronics and consumer goods. Mr Trump's approval ratings are falling due to his handling of tariffs and the economy. The volatile run-up to the Geneva talks underscores the deep mistrust and divergent negotiating styles between the Trump team and China, which could make for protracted and fraught discussions. Scott Kennedy, an expert in Chinese business affairs at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) in Washington, said "Both sides I think are balancing trying to look tough with not wanting to be responsible for sinking the global economy". After Mr Trump's tariff salvo last month, China took a hard line in its public messaging. The tone began to shift on April 30, when a state media-affiliated blog said the US. had "proactively reached out to China through multiple channels, hoping to discuss tariffs". Contacts between Chinese agencies, Beijing's embassy in Washington, and the Trump administration had been increasing in frequency in recent weeks. Some in-person interactions took place at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings in late April, including with US treasury secretary Scott Bessent, which paved the way for the Swiss meeting, said Kennedy. After Mr Trump's "Liberation Day" tariffs, Chinese commerce minister Wang Wentao quietly reached out to his US counterpart, Howard Lutnick, but was rebuffed as not senior enough, according to one official familiar with the exchanges. Mr Trump has been pushing for direct talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping. China has rejected that idea as not in keeping with its traditional approach of working out the details first before the leaders sign any deal. Another significant factor for China was Mr Trump's public berating of Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy in February, said one of the sources, adding that any unscripted hostile interaction between the US and Chinese leaders would represent an unacceptable loss of face for Mr Xi. As messaging on both sides grew more conciliatory, China decided to put forward its vice premier and Xi confidant He Lifeng, whose direct predecessor struck the "Phase One" trade deal with the US in 2019. The move satisfied Washington's demands for substantive talks with a senior official with direct access to Mr Xi, but avoided exposing the Chinese leader to potential embarrassment, said one of the sources. The Swiss foreign ministry said that "during its recent contacts in Washington and Beijing, Switzerland expressed to the US and Chinese authorities its willingness to organize a meeting between the two parties in Geneva." Among the main drivers of Beijing's climb-down were internal signals that Chinese companies were struggling to avoid bankruptcies and to replace the US market, three people familiar with the Chinese government's thinking said. US diplomats in China have also been closely monitoring factory closures, strikes, and job losses in the industrial heartland in southern China. Many analysts have downgraded their 2025 economic growth forecasts for China, and investment bank Nomura has warned the trade war could cost it up to 16 million jobs. China's central bank this week announced fresh monetary stimulus. One of the officials said Chinese companies were struggling to replace the US market because developing nations cannot buy as many items, and that for many firms this was an existential threat that needed to be resolved in days or weeks. Beijing was worried it was left without a place at the negotiating table while its major trading partners, such as Vietnam, India and Japan, began talks with Washington, said two officials familiar with Beijing's thinking. China's commerce ministry said in a statement this week that "appeasement cannot bring peace, compromise cannot be respected, and adhering to principled positions and upholding fairness and justice is the right way to safeguard one's own interests." As part of the push to counter the US, China is sending its Premier Li Qiang to Malaysia in late May for a summit with a newly established group of Southeast Asian and Arab nations, two sources told Reuters. In Geneva, Beijing appears to have modest expectations. Internally, China has downgraded the talks from a higher level to merely a meeting, reflecting its view that the discussions will be mostly about finding out Washington's demands and red lines after weeks of contradictory messages by Mr Trump and other senior US officials, according to a person familiar with the matter. One official said China could draw on its extensive toolbox and follow Asian neighbors in offering to buy more American liquefied natural gas. On the table may also be purchases of agricultural goods, similar to the 2019 "Phase One" deal during Trump's first term. At the time, Beijing said it would increase purchases of US agricultural products by $32bn (‚Ç¨28bn) over two years. Even before triggering the broader trade war, Trump imposed a 20% tariff on Chinese goods, saying Beijing wasn't doing enough to counter the flow of chemicals used to produce the deadly drug fentanyl. One of the moves that complicated the rapprochement, according to two officials, was a letter sent by the US to China in late April that outlined the steps Trump wanted Beijing to take on fentanyl. The document, reviewed by Reuters, caused friction with Beijing because it referenced a congressional report that asserted China, through value-added tax rebates for exporters, directly subsidizes production of fentanyl precursors for sale abroad. The letter, sent to the ministries of foreign affairs, commerce, and public security, called on Beijing to publicize the crackdown on fentanyl precursors on the front page of the Communist Party mouthpiece People's Daily; send a similar message through "internal party channels" to party members; tighten regulation of some specified chemicals; and deepen law-enforcement cooperation. Two officials familiar with China's reaction said it found especially the first two points "arrogant" because Beijing saw it as the US dictating what China should do within its ruling apparatus. One said fentanyl would feature in the Geneva talks and that the US government's opening position would be to present the four points to China. title: Britain‚Äôs Roller-Coaster Ride to a Trade Deal With Trump
content: At times during weeks of thorny negotiations, the efforts of Prime Minister Keir Starmer‚Äôs government seemed destined to fail.
resumen: For Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, the road to a first-in-the-world trade deal with the United States began on a late winter afternoon when he arrived in the Oval Office, bearing a letter for President Trump from King Charles III, inviting Mr. Trump for a rare second state visit to Britain. It ended on Thursday afternoon when Mr. Starmer was patched into the Oval Office for a theatrical, televised phone call with Mr. Trump, in which the president announced a deal that will roll back tariffs on some British exports, including autos and steel, while leaving other tariffs in place. The deal, Mr. Trump declared, will be ‚Äúso good for both countries.‚Äù Mr. Starmer said the agreement testified to the value of not being provoked by Mr. Trump‚Äôs sometimes aggressive tactics. The nine weeks between Mr. Starmer‚Äôs visit in February and his phone call Thursday with Mr. Trump were a roller-coaster ride for the prime minister and his negotiators. Kim Darroch said, critics could argue that Mr. Trump had not lifted all the tariffs and might yet reverse course on elements of the agreement. On April 2, Britain was swept into the same basic 10 percent tariff that the United States imposed on dozens of countries. Its steel and auto industry had already been slapped with tariffs. Mr. Starmer has tried to act as a bridge between Mr. Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine. Mr. Starmer said in an interview with The New York Times in March, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve met him a number of times now. I‚Äôve spoken to him on numerous cases on the phone. I think we have a really good relationship.‚Äù Among the issues the two leaders discussed was Mr. Trump‚Äôs golf club in Scotland, Trump Turnberry. In late March, Mr. Starmer told the president that the police had arrested three people on suspicion of vandalizing the resort with pro-Palestinian messages. Mr. Trump referred to them as ‚Äúterrorists.‚Äù British officials pushed back against Mr. Trump‚Äôs claim that Mr. Starmer was ‚Äúvery happy‚Äù that Britain had only been hit with a 10 percent tariff, not 20 percent, as had the European Union. Part of the challenge for Britain, a senior official said, was toggling between Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, and Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary. British officials also expressed anxiety that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent might prioritize securing an agreement with a larger Asian economy like Japan. Britain was helped in the negotiation by having Peter Mandelson as its new ambassador to Washington. During Mr. Trump‚Äôs phone call with Mr. Starmer on Thursday, Mr. Mandelson stood behind the president in the Oval Office. The breakthrough came on Wednesday, when British negotiators in Washington called Jonathan Reynolds, the country‚Äôs secretary for business and trade, to ask whether the government would greenlight the latest draft of the deal, which it did. Mr. Trump still placed one last call to Mr. Starmer, seeking concessions, on Wednesday night in London. Mr. Starmer decided to travel to a Jaguar Land Rover factory, outside Birmingham, to showcase how the deal would cut tariffs on cars from about 25 percent to 10 percent.

title: Baffled by the Trump Tariffs, C.E.O.s Lean on the Word ‚ÄòUncertainty‚Äô
content: With little ability to see how far the Trump administration is taking its disruptive policies, corporations and investors face higher risks, our columnist says.
resumen:
Ford and General Motors executives say they can‚Äôt estimate what lies ahead. Both companies have suspended earnings guidance. A broad range of companies, including Delta Air Lines, Southwest Airlines, Skechers, UPS and Cummins, say they can‚Äôt talk confidently about the future.

Executives used ‚Äúuncertainty‚Äù in 87 percent of earnings calls this season, compared with 38 percent in the previous three months. Executives used ‚Äútariffs‚Äù in 93 percent of earnings calls. ‚ÄúRecession‚Äù came up in 30 percent of these discussions, versus 3 percent in the previous quarter.

Sherry House, Ford‚Äôs chief financial officer, said they are suspending guidance for full year 2025. She enumerated some of the things that Ford doesn‚Äôt know: industrywide supply chain disruption impacting production; future or increased tariffs in the U.S.; changes in the implementation of tariffs, including tariff offsets; retaliatory tariffs and other restrictions by other governments and the potential related market impacts; and finally, policy uncertainties associated with tax and emissions policy.

President Trump wants the U.S. military to enter Mexico to fight the drug cartels. He urged Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico‚Äôs president, to approve a U.S. military incursion. She responded: ‚ÄúI told him, ‚ÄòNo, President Trump, our territory is inviolable, our sovereignty is inviolable, our sovereignty is not for sale.‚Äù She added, ‚ÄúWe will never accept the presence of the army of the United States on our territory.‚Äù

In a White House meeting with Mark Carney, Canada‚Äôs new prime minister, Mr. Trump insisted that one day Canada would become the 51st state. Prime Minister Carney quickly responded: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not for sale it won‚Äôt be for sale, ever.‚Äù Mr. Trump said, ‚ÄúNever say never.‚Äù

Tim Cook, Apple‚Äôs chief executive, said on a May 1 earnings call that tariffs in the three months starting in June are most likely to add $900 million to Apple‚Äôs costs. He said that estimate assumes ‚Äúthe current global tariff rates, policies and applications do not change for the balance of the quarter, and no new tariffs are added.‚Äù Mr. Cook warned that ‚Äúthis estimate should not be used to make projections for future quarters.‚Äù

Mr. Cook said, ‚ÄúWe do expect the majority of iPhones sold in the U.S. will have India as their country of origin and Vietnam to be the country of origin for almost all iPad, Mac, Apple Watch and AirPods products. China would continue to be the country of origin for the vast majority of total product sales outside the U.S.‚Äù

U.S. tariffs on many Chinese products now stand at 145 percent. Apple, is, for now, benefiting from a temporary exemption from tariffs on smartphones from China.

The first official U.S.-Chinese meeting since the start of the trade conflict is scheduled for this weekend in Geneva.

The Federal Reserve said in a statement this past week, ‚ÄúUncertainty about the economic outlook has increased further.‚Äù Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said in a news conference, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much uncertainty about the scale, scope, timing and persistence of the tariffs.‚Äù The Fed will hold interest rates steady.

Stock analysts are projecting a deceleration in profit growth for U.S. corporations, but they have not, for the most part, included the possibility of a recession. They are penciling in a likely reduction in the rate of profit growth this year ‚Äî but expect profits to keep growing ‚Äî with a re-acceleration in 2026.

The deal includes:
*   Reducing tariffs on cars exported to the US from 27.5% to 10% for a quota of 100,000 UK cars.
*   Scrapping the 25% tariffs on UK steel and aluminum imported by the US.
*   "Reciprocal market access" on beef, with a quota for UK farmers to export 13,000 metric tonnes of beef to the US, and the US granted the same.
*   Creating a secure supply chain for pharmaceutical products, with final details to be written up in the coming weeks.
*   Preferential access for the US to high-quality UK aerospace components.
*   The reciprocal tariff rate of 10% on the UK, which was announced in March, remains in place.

Chancellor Rachel Reeves described the deal as a "good deal." Treasury Minister Darren Jones said that 150,000 jobs had been "protected."

Shadow trade secretary Andrew Griffith said that a more "comprehensive" agreement is needed to grow the UK economy.

British Airways' parent company announced it had bought 32 new Boeing planes from the US.

Liam Bates, from stainless steel manufacturer Marcegaglia, said the announcement was "very significant," but adds that it would "be good to get more clarity."

Farmers have also had a mixed reaction to the deal.

The US-UK trade deal has been described as "historic" by both Trump and Starmer.

Economists have weighed in on the situation saying that, though the lack of concessions on the UK side could be viewed as a success, the deal is unlikely to boost Britain's economy much.

The UK's digital services tax was not revised as part of the deal.

The Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, welcomed the tariff pact struck between the US and the UK.

The director general of UK Steel says the industry is still waiting to learn the exact details of yesterday's UK-US trade agreement.

The Governor of the Bank of England has said the UK now needs to "rebuild" Britain's trade relationship with the European Union.

Sheffield steel manufacturer Liam Bates, president of Marcegaglia says the news is "very significant."

Car manufacturer Jaguar Land Rover says the deal "secures greater certainty for our sector" after import charges were lowered from 25% to 10% on the first 100,000 exports.

Ian McCubbine, a beef farmer in Surrey, tells BBC Radio 4's Today programme that "we have to be careful that we are stringent about food standards."

title: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq waver as focus turns to China talks, Trump floats cut to tariffs on Chinese imports
content: Wall Street digested the latest signs President Trump's trade war could be entering a more conciliatory phase.
resumen: US stocks wobbled on Friday after President Trump hinted more trade deals are coming and raised the possibility of a cut to US tariffs on Chinese imports ahead of talks between the two countries this weekend. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) erased opening gains to drop 0.3%. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) closed below the flatline, while the Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) was little changed. All three major averages ended the week down less than 0.5%. Markets are focused on the US-China trade talks in Geneva this weekend. As reports flagged a potential US cut to sky-high tariffs on Chinese imports, Trump said an 80% rate "seems right" in a post to Truth Social on Friday. The president this week has maintained an optimistic tone about the talks with China. Hopes for a deescalation in tariff tensions got a further boost on Friday as Trump said, "Many Trade Deals in the hopper, all good (GREAT!) ones" in a later social media post. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) was rallying against the dollar amid the optimism, trading above $102,000 after topping $104,000 overnight. On the earnings front, Pinterest (PINS) stock surged following an upbeat quarterly revenue outlook. Expedia (EXPE) slid after the online booking platform missed revenue estimates amid flagging US demand. Stocks notched weekly losses as investors turned their focus to talks between China and the US happening this weekend in Switzerland. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) dropped about 0.3%. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) fell below the flatline. The Nasdaq Composite (IXIC) was flat. Tesla (TSLA) stock jumped more than 4%, pushing shares to their highest level since February. Investor optimism grew this week after the US and UK announced a trade deal, and President Trump hinted he would be willing to lower tariff rates on imports from China from 145% to perhaps 80%. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will be meeting with Chinese officials this weekend to talk about trade. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters on Friday afternoon that President Trump ‚Äúthrew out there‚Äù the 80% rate for tariffs on imports from China. Leavitt said no final rate would be set prior to the upcoming talks this weekend between Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Chinese officials in Switzerland. On Friday morning Trump posted on social media "80% Tariff on China seems right! Up to Scott B.". Stocks were on pace to close out the week with modest losses on Friday, as investors turned their focus to talks between China and the US happening this weekend in Switzerland. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) erased early morning losses to drop 0.2%. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) and the Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) wavered between positive and negative territory for much of the session. Industrial stocks (XLI) outperformed this week, along with Energy (XLE). Tech (XLK) was on pace to gain less than 0.5% for the week. Meanwhile, Healthcare (XLV) stocks sank for the week. Tesla (TSLA) stock surged as much as 7% before paring gains on Friday, helping send the Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) into green territory. At 12:25 p.m. ET, shares were up more than 4%. Tesla is also set to close out the week with the biggest gains among the megacap group, up more than 3%. Pinterest (PINS) stock soared over 10% after the social media platform issued upbeat guidance and reported it had 570 million monthly active users in the first quarter. Boeing (BA) stock rose 1% after the plane maker emerged as a winner in the US-UK trade pact. Lyft (LYFT) shares surged more than 16% after Engine Capital said on Friday it would end its activist campaign in the ride-hailing company and withdraw its board nominees after the company increased its stock buyback program to $750 million from $500 million. Stocks rose at the open on Wall Street on Friday after President Trump suggested cutting US tariffs on Chinese imports. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) edged up 0.2%. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) rose 0.4%, while the Nasdaq Composite (IXIC) gained about 0.5%. In a social media post on Friday morning, Trump suggested an 80% tariff rate for Chinese imports. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) extended gains on Friday, rising 3.6% to trade above $103,000. At one point, the world's largest cryptocurrency briefly spiked above $104,000. Bitcoin fell as low as $75,000 in the days following Trump's "reciprocal" tariff announcement on April 2. It's now trading around its highest level since January. The crypto is not very far off from its all-time high of 109,114.88 reached on Jan. 20, Trump's Inauguration Day. Stock futures jumped premarket after President Trump posted on social media that he is considering slashing tariffs on Chinese imports ahead of the highly anticipated meeting between US and Chinese officials this weekend. "80% Tariff on China seems right! Up to Scott B.," Trump wrote on Truth Social. S&P 500 futures (ES=F) were up 0.2%, while futures on the Nasdaq (NQ=F) and Dow Jones Industrial Average (YM=F) rose 0.3% and 0.1%, respectively. Oil prices are gaining to end the week on trade optimism after the US and UK announced they reached a trade agreement on Thursday and signs point to deescalation in the trade war with China. Brent futures (BZ=F), the international benchmark, rose 1.8% to trade around $64 per barrel, while West Texas Intermediate futures (CL=F) gained 2% on Friday morning, trading around $61 per barrel. Pinterest's (PINS) upbeat forecast for quarterly revenue calmed some worries about the prospects for ad spending as tariff risks weigh on the economic outlook. The social media platform provider's shares jumped 12% in premarket trading. Nvidia (NVDA) unveiled plans for a less-capable model of the H20 AI chips for use in China in response to the US an export restrictions on the most powerful chips made by American chip producers. title: US-China trade talks could temper tariff angst, but rivalry runs deep
content: It‚Äôs unlikely the U.S. and China can erase the tension in their geopolitical rivalry. But they can manage it. The current talks provide a key avenue.
resumen:
Representatives from the United States and China will meet for talks in Geneva on Saturday, taking the first step toward normalizing a key economic partnership. President Donald Trump appears ready to ease tensions between the world‚Äôs two biggest economies. On Friday, he posted on the Truth Social network that 80% tariffs on China ‚Äúseems right.‚Äù Bloomberg reports the administration could aim to negotiate its duties on Chinese imports down to 60%, more than halving the current rate of 145%. Reports say China has drawn up a list of American products that might be exempt from its 125% tariffs.

If America‚Äôs current tariffs stayed in place, China‚Äôs economic growth rate this year could drop by as much as a third, jeopardizing millions of Chinese jobs. Chinese factory activity fell to nearly a two-year low. China‚Äôs outbound shipments to the U.S. were valued at $33 billion in April, a 21% decline from April 2024. Overall, however, there was an unexpected increase of 8.1% in China‚Äôs exports for April.

Economists expect higher prices and lower growth, with the nation possibly slipping into a period of relative stagnation coupled with inflation, a situation known as stagflation. Odds of an outright recession, in which the economy actually contracts, are also growing.

The U.S.-British trade deal announced Thursday is narrow, reducing auto and steel tariffs but keeping a 10% tariff on most British goods in place. Washington and Beijing face a much broader set of trade disputes that will take longer to iron out.

Another faction within the Trump administration wants to slow China‚Äôs growth to maintain U.S. geopolitical supremacy.

China‚Äôs goal is to lower tariffs.

A Thursday commentary in the Communist Party mouthpiece People‚Äôs Daily stated that China has stood up to the United States‚Äô ‚Äúillegal‚Äù tariffs and ‚Äúblackmail‚Äù not only to defend its own interests, but also to defend ‚Äúinternational fairness and justice.‚Äù

If they reach a deal, it most likely would be an agreement for China to take steps to reduce its trade surplus and the US to commit to a predictable level of tariffs and other restrictions for a certain period.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent testifies on Capitol Hill in Washington, May 6, 2025.

In the short term, advantage China. In 18 months, many of President Trump‚Äôs Republican allies in Congress will stand for reelection.

China has more to lose economically from an extended trade war because it sells far more to the U.S. than the U.S. sells to it. So in the long term, America probably has the advantage.

Economist Stephen Roach in his 2014 book, ‚ÄúUnbalanced: The Codependency of America and China.‚Äù

China needs to shift some focus and spending to services like those of other advanced economies. The pandemic, a property market collapse, and now the trade war have sapped China‚Äôs consumer confidence. China‚Äôs leadership has elevated national security to an equal footing with growth in terms of importance.

title: Trade War Shock Is Scrambling China‚Äôs Exports
content: Shipments of goods to the United States plunged by 21 percent in April, but spiked to Asia as President Trump imposed sky-high tariffs on China.
resumen:
Datos del gobierno chino publicados el viernes ofrecieron una visi√≥n de c√≥mo la guerra comercial ya est√° reordenando el flujo de bienes en todo el mundo.

Las exportaciones de China aumentaron el mes pasado, impulsadas por el comercio con otros pa√≠ses del sudeste asi√°tico, incluso cuando los aranceles del presidente Trump sobre los productos chinos forzaron una fuerte desaceleraci√≥n en los env√≠os a Estados Unidos.

Dentro de China, las importaciones cayeron a medida que la demanda continu√≥ debilit√°ndose.

Las cifras comerciales publicadas el viernes capturan la actividad en abril, cuando las tensiones entre Estados Unidos y China se intensificaron m√°s r√°pidamente de lo esperado. En una serie de medidas, el Sr. Trump elev√≥ los aranceles sobre los productos chinos al 145 por ciento, y China respondi√≥ con grav√°menes del 125 por ciento sobre los productos estadounidenses.

Como resultado, los env√≠os chinos a Estados Unidos se desplomaron un 21 por ciento con respecto al a√±o anterior. Pero las exportaciones chinas a los pa√≠ses del sudeste asi√°tico se dispararon un 21 por ciento.

"Esta es una se√±al temprana de que algo est√° pasando en t√©rminos de una carga frontal de la cadena de suministro", dijo Raymond Yeung, economista jefe para la Gran China de ANZ, un banco de Nueva Zelanda. "Es una redirecci√≥n del comercio que ya est√° bien documentada".

Las exportaciones chinas a pa√≠ses como Vietnam y Tailandia se han disparado, dijo el Sr. Yeung, mientras que los datos sobre las importaciones de Taiw√°n y Corea del Sur sugirieron que las f√°bricas chinas estaban aprovechando una pausa de 90 d√≠as en los aranceles en los pa√≠ses de la regi√≥n para completar los pedidos destinados a Estados Unidos.

Los env√≠os generales de bienes desde China en abril aumentaron un 8,1 por ciento con respecto al a√±o anterior. Los datos mostraron la continuaci√≥n de una tendencia en los √∫ltimos meses, con f√°bricas chinas que se apresuraron a enviar bienes a medida que la guerra comercial empeoraba. Muchos de esos bienes terminaron en algunos de los pa√≠ses orientados a la exportaci√≥n de la Asociaci√≥n de Naciones del Sudeste Asi√°tico de 10 miembros, o ASEAN.

"Los productores nacionales han detenido la mayor parte de su producci√≥n dirigida al mercado estadounidense, pero est√°n preparando productos para los pa√≠ses de la ASEAN porque es all√≠ donde han establecido sus f√°bricas en preparaci√≥n para esta situaci√≥n", dijo Dan Wang, director del equipo de China de Eurasia Group.

En los √∫ltimos a√±os, a medida que la econom√≠a interna de China se ha visto obstaculizada por un colapso del mercado de la vivienda, el gobierno se ha apoyado m√°s en el env√≠o de sus bienes al extranjero. La crisis inmobiliaria se ha extendido por el resto de la econom√≠a y ha dejado a los bancos y gobiernos locales atascados con montones de deuda, y los j√≥venes han luchado con menos opciones de trabajo.

Es probable que los datos de abril den a los responsables pol√≠ticos de Beijing un respiro en medio de preocupaciones m√°s amplias sobre el impacto de la guerra comercial en las perspectivas econ√≥micas de China. Pero los economistas advierten que el desempleo podr√≠a dispararse si la disminuci√≥n de los pedidos de las f√°bricas obliga a las empresas a despedir trabajadores. Las f√°bricas chinas experimentaron su mayor desaceleraci√≥n mensual en m√°s de un a√±o en abril.

Los reguladores financieros chinos se√±alaron esta semana que estaban listos para intervenir para impulsar la demanda interna para capear el impacto de la guerra comercial. El banco central recort√≥ las tasas de inter√©s y afloj√≥ los grifos de dinero para dirigir m√°s dinero a la econom√≠a para alentar a las empresas y a las personas a gastar.

Scott Bessent, el secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, y Jamieson Greer, el representante comercial de Estados Unidos, se reunir√°n con el viceprimer ministro de China, He Lifeng, en Ginebra este fin de semana, la primera reuni√≥n formal sobre comercio desde que el Sr. Trump elev√≥ los aranceles a los tres d√≠gitos en abril.

title: Currency hedging and new U.S. factories: Novo Nordisk CFO thinks Wegovy maker can outmaneuver global trade wars
content: Novo Nordisk is hedging and building its way around a global tariff war that may threaten the Wegovy maker‚Äôs plans to expand in the U.S. Karsten Munk Knudsen, Novo Nordisk‚Äôs chief financial officer, ...
resumen:
Karsten Munk Knudsen, chief financial officer of Novo Nordisk, told Fortune the company is well-placed to handle the geopolitical upheaval that rocked global business in March and April.

Novo Nordisk‚Äôs native Denmark is also locked in a tense diplomatic battle with the U.S. over the status of the territory of Greenland, which could yet bring consequences for trade between the countries.

Knudsen wouldn‚Äôt be drawn on hypothetical duties threatened by Trump in April, when he promised ‚Äúmajor tariffs‚Äù that would be coming ‚Äúvery shortly‚Äù to pharmaceutical imports.

A second priority, though, is building Novo Nordisk‚Äôs U.S. infrastructure. The company already has 10,000 employees in the States, while Knudsen pointed out it had invested $24 billion in the U.S. over the last decade.

Novo Nordisk CEO Lars Fruergaard J√∏rgensen said on the company‚Äôs Q1 earnings call on Wednesday as he played down tariff uncertainty.

The group is constructing a $4.1 billion North Carolina plant, where it will produce its injectable Wegovy weight loss medication. J√∏rgensen said that a world-first oral GLP-1, submitted for approval to the FDA in early May, would also be produced in the U.S.

The drugmaker says guidance could be negatively affected by fresh tariffs.

Knudsen told Fortune, ‚ÄúIt's not like we are totally insulated and without exposure, but I think we have a reasonable hedge for many scenarios.‚Äù

Novo Nordisk hedges between 50% and 70% of its foreign currency reserves. With U.S. sales accounting for more than half of the company‚Äôs top line, a lot of hedging attention is given to the U.S. dollar. The dollar has fallen by 8% against the Danish krone since the start of 2025.

The company expects to make a DKK 0.9 billion ($136 million) gain in 2025, largely related to its hedges on the U.S. dollar. Back in February, prior to the tariff whirlwind, the company expected to make a DKK 9 billion ($1.4 billion) loss on its hedging strategy.

Knudsen said Novo Nordisk planned to stick to its hedging strategy ‚Äúwith some minor tweaks.‚Äù

Novo Nordisk, with its expansion in the U.S., is one of many threatening to hasten that expansion if EU policymakers fail to undergo a regulatory and intellectual property overhaul.

Knudsen said, ‚ÄúIf European politicians keep pushing pharma down and making it less and less attractive, then of course, as any other industry, we believe that that would be a loss for the European Union.‚Äù

title: Get the Facts: How President Trump's tariffs with Canada have evolved
content: This week marked an important milestone in the state of trade between the United States and Canada. Since February, the United States and Canada have entered into a series of trade measures and ...
resumen:
This week marked an important milestone in the state of trade between the United States and Canada.

President Donald Trump met with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney on Tuesday.

Carney, a former central banker who assumed office after Prime Minister Justin Trudeau resigned as leader of the center-left Liberal Party, won the Canadian election last week and has vowed to take on Trump and his tariffs.

During Trump's first term in office, the United States entered into a trade agreement called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or USMCA, which was signed on July 1, 2020.

On Feb. 1, 2025, Trump signed an executive order implementing a 25% additional tariff on imports from Canada and a 10% additional tariff on energy and potash, which was put on pause for 30 days a couple of days after the announcement.

Since then, the United States and Canada have entered into a series of trade measures and countermeasures.

In March, Canada started to impose counter-tariffs against the United States.

On March 4, Canada added tariffs on $30 billion worth of American goods in response to the 25% tariffs on Canadian exports and 10% tariffs on energy product exports.

When Trump imposed 25% tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum products, Canada imposed countermeasures on March 12.

In April, when Trump's 25% tariff on Canadian automobiles took effect, Canada imposed 25% tariffs on vehicles from the United States that did not comply with USMCA.

Since the reciprocal tariffs were announced on April 2, Trump has reduced the tariffs to 10% across the board, implemented a 90-day pause, and raised tariffs on Chinese goods to 145%.

Canada was the top destination for U.S. exports and the third-largest source of U.S. imports in 2024.

Around $412.7 billion worth of goods were imported from Canada in 2024.

The meeting at the Oval Office between Carney and Trump on Tuesday bore no solutions to tariffs.

title: America's small businesses preparing for recession with Trump tariffs: CNBC|SurveyMonkey survey
content: Tariffs are not just impacting consumers and big corporations, but small businesses too, and that‚Äôs leading a majority on Main Street to brace for a recession.
resumen:
According to the latest quarterly CNBC|SurveyMonkey Small Business Survey, just 30% of small business owners said they would rate the current state of the economy as excellent or good. 70% said it's fair or poor. In the first quarter's poll, 39% rated the state of the economy as excellent or good.

70% of small business owners believe the country is headed towards a recession. Nearly all Democrat respondents forecast a recession while nearly half of Republicans did (47%) as well.

51% of respondents said they disapprove of the way Donald Trump is handling his job as president. This compares to 39% during his last quarter as president in 2020.

Small business confidence tracked by the survey is now lower than at any point during Trump's first term, other than during the worst quarter of the Covid crisis and the last quarter of his presidency.

The CNBC/SurveyMonkey poll was conducted between April 21-25, 2025, among a national sample of 2,257 self-identified small business owners.

51% of respondents said that they expect changes in trade policy to have a negative effect on their business over the next 12 months, compared to 27% that said it will have no effect and 21% that said it will have a positive effect.

Overall, 66% of small business owners either have been or expect to be impacted by tariffs.

Tariffs increased to 17%, up from 10% last quarter, while inflation (24%) and consumer demand (18%) remain the top risks listed by small business owners.

U.S. Chamber of Commerce CEO Suzanne Clark said the business lobbying group has been "inundated by small business requests for information, for relief" from the potential tariffs.

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has appealed to the Trump White House to automatically lift tariffs on all small business importers.

In a letter sent on April 30 to Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer, Clark wrote, "We are deeply concerned that even if it only takes weeks or months to reach agreements, many small businesses will suffer irreparable harm."

The White House has not acted on those requests.

60% of respondents said they are either very or somewhat stressed about their businesses' finances these days, while 63% said they are very stressed or somewhat stressed about their own finances.

Tariffs ranked second as a contributor of stress.

Fed Chair Jerome Powell warned that the proposed tariffs could lead to a slowdown in economic growth and potentially a rise in long-term inflation.

President Trump said in a Truth Social post that he might be willing to lower tariffs on China to 80%.

title: They‚Äôve watched democracies fail. They see it happening under Trump.
content: As Donald Trump fights the courts over Kilmar Abrego Garcia, targets law firms, and tests the rule of law, democracy experts warn they‚Äôve seen this before.
resumen:
The article discusses concerns about President Donald Trump's actions and their potential impact on American democracy and the rule of law. It highlights several key points:

*   **Deportations and Judicial Challenges:** The Trump administration faced court challenges regarding deportations, specifically focusing on Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Salvadoran national. A Justice Department attorney admitted in court that Mr. Abrego Garcia had been sent back to his native country because of an ‚Äúadministrative error.‚Äù The Supreme Court ruled that the Trump administration needed to ‚Äúfacilitate‚Äù Mr. Abrego Garcia‚Äôs return, but President Trump and Salvadoran President Nayib Bukele indicated they would not comply.
*   **Comparison to Authoritarian Tactics:** Experts suggest that President Trump is following a pattern seen in other countries where democracies have declined. This includes actions like intimidating opposition, defying courts, punishing the media, and favoring loyalists.

*   **Defiance of Court Rulings:** The article notes that President Trump has tested the courts' power and, in some instances, openly defied court rulings.
*   **Executive Power and Constraints:** The administration is seeking to limit the power of lower courts and has invoked the Alien Enemies Act to remove individuals.
*   **Targeting of Critics:** The article details instances where the Trump administration has targeted individuals and groups critical of the president, including lawyers, government employees, and law firms.
*   **Comparison to Other Countries:** The article draws parallels between President Trump's actions and those of leaders in countries like Hungary and El Salvador, where democratic institutions have been weakened.
*   **Concerns from Experts and Officials:** The article includes quotes from experts, political scientists, and Republican senators expressing concerns about the direction of American democracy.
*   **Impact on Civil Liberties:** The article highlights the potential impact of the administration's actions on civil rights and liberties, citing examples of individuals being targeted and facing legal challenges.
*   **The Role of the Courts:** The article emphasizes the importance of judicial independence and the balance of power in a liberal democracy.
*   **The "Hollowing Out" of Democracy:** The article suggests that the U.S. is experiencing a gradual erosion of democratic norms and institutions, with the system being "captured" from within.

title: How a Chinese delicacy got caught in the crossfire of Trump‚Äôs trade war
content: But the escalating trade war between the U.S. and China is now crippling an entire industry that hand-harvests geoducks, leaving Washington state divers without work, Seattle exporters without ...
resumen: Joshua George, a Suquamish tribal member, has been diving for geoducks in the Salish Sea for over two decades. The geoduck, the world‚Äôs largest burrowing clam, has been harvested by George‚Äôs Indigenous ancestors in the Pacific Northwest since before Europeans arrived and has become a delicacy in China. Washington state sends 90% of its geoducks to China. The escalating trade war between the U.S. and China is crippling the geoduck harvesting industry. U.S. President Donald Trump placed tariffs of at least 145% on China, which led China to retaliate with tariffs of 125% on the U.S. The meaty mollusk is often sliced raw for crisp sashimi out west while China consumers prefer it chewy in stir-fries or hot pot soups. Pre-tariff costs were as high as $100 per pound in restaurants. The trade war has had an immediate, direct effect on the delicate geoducks, which are shipped alive the same day of harvest. The millions of pounds of geoducks shipped annually to China come from two main sources: wild harvests on tracts of seafloor that are split between the Washington State Department of Natural Resources and Puget Sound Treaty Indian Tribes, and tideland farms. Last year, the state and tribes collectively harvested about 3.4 million pounds of wild Washington geoduck for sale. The state generated $22.4 million in revenue for their half of the clams. As of late April, Washington state divers had only pulled about half of the expected harvest from the state tracts. The Suquamish operation has no orders to harvest for at the moment. The American trade war has inadvertently boosted the Canadian geoduck business, which is facing a mere 25% tariff from China. Washington state in the U.S. and Canada‚Äôs British Columbia province are the two primary places where the wild geoducks grow naturally for commercial harvest. James Austin, president of Canada‚Äôs Underwater Harvesters Association, expects there will be 2.75 million pounds of Canadian geoducks harvested in 2025, worth approximately $43.4 million USD in revenue. After Canada got hit with a 25% tariff in March, export sale prices dropped to $12 per pound, and after the U.S. got hit with a 125% tariff in April, Canadian geoducks are now being sold for $17 a pound. Yang Bin at Beihai Huaxiashougang Health Industry Company in Beihai city of Guangxi province in China said their seafood wholesale important business no longer gets geoduck from the U.S. Derrick McRae and his brother pulled up about 800 pounds of wild geoducks in just one April day. Farmer Ian Child said the tariff disruption is not just hurting his bottom line but the entire farming process.

title: Freight shipper says ‚Äòmillions‚Äô of businesses in peril from China tariffs

Petersen attended the Hill and Valley Forum, a consortium of U.S. lawmakers and venture capitalists that first convened in 2023 to combat China‚Äôs influence in the U.S. technology industry. Petersen launched his San Francisco-based company in 2013. ‚ÄúI think a lot of companies will fail if this goes on longer,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúCertainly, if this went on for a quarter, you‚Äôd have mass failure of small and medium-sized businesses.‚Äù Flexport is a freight middleman. Since its inception, more than 13,000 companies of all sizes have used Flexport‚Äôs logistics and technology to move more than $175 billion in merchandise. title: Trump‚Äôs trade war is about to change the way you shop
content: You‚Äôre about to feel the effects of President Donald Trump‚Äôs trade war every time you shop. In a matter of weeks, infinite varieties, colors, sizes and flavors will be replaced with smaller selections ...
resumen: President Donald Trump's trade war is about to change the way you shop. In a matter of weeks, infinite varieties, colors, sizes and flavors will be replaced with smaller selections, fewer options and limited choice. As free trade blossomed over the past five decades, the number of imported goods on shelves tripled between 1972 and 2001, research shows, equivalent to a 2.6% rise in GDP. Grocery stores now stock around 30,000 different items, Walmart sells 120,000 goods at its superstores and Amazon‚Äôs online catalog contains millions of products. Trump has implemented a 10% universal tariff on virtually every product entering the United States ‚Äî with higher rates for certain goods ‚Äî and 145% tariffs on China. Jason Miller, a professor in supply chain management at Michigan State University, said that the tariffs will result in far less variety. Companies are struggling with tough decisions over which products they can still offer under the steep tariffs, eliminating items that are either too expensive to produce or that shoppers will abandon over price hikes. Companies are cancelling products made in China and buying only their top-selling items from manufacturers in other countries where they can negotiate lower prices. They are also suspending product launches and new innovations they‚Äôve spent years preparing. Sarah Wells, the founder of an eponymous brand of backpacks, totes and other breast-feeding products, said that she will only be selling her best-selling version of her breast pump backpacks in black or one other color, such as brown or gray, once she runs out of inventory. Wells halted ordering products from China last month because of the 145% tariffs. She found a manufacturer in Cambodia, but intentionally limited her first inventory order to bags with the highest demand and profit margins. Wells expects to be sold out of some of her top sellers by July. Some items may not return until next year, if ever. Marina Rosin Levine, the CEO of Highline United, which owns Ash and Isaac Mizrahi and produces private-label footwear, said that Ash pulled boots off the site to hold them for the fall, unsure if there will be enough inventory during the season. It also cut product orders from China and narrowed its orders from its manufacturers in Vietnam. Hasbro, the owner of Nerf, Play-Doh and other toys and games, is cutting some items that won‚Äôt be profitable with 145% tariffs on China. Roughly 80% of toys sold in the United States are made in China, according to the Toy Association, an industry group. Newell Brands will also reduce the variety of baby gear it sells because of tariffs on China. Around 97% of baby strollers and 87% of children‚Äôs car seats in the United States are sourced from China, the company said. Newell CEO Christopher Peterson said the company in recent years has cut its product variety from 100,000 items to under 20,000. Discount retailers Dollar Tree and Five Below, clothing brand Vince and Acco Brands have also signaled they will discontinue some items because of tariffs. Vince finance chief Yuji Okumura said that there will definitely be a little bit of (product) reduction. Shawn Nelson, the CEO of furniture retailer Lovesac, said that the companies in best position to succeed in this new era of protectionism will be more specialized and have slimmer product catalogs. Bobby Djavaheri, the president of Yedi Houseware, a kitchen and small appliances‚Äô company, told CNN that they are shelving ideas for new creative small appliances. Sarah Wells has also stopped creating new designs of bags and styles.

title: Trump, Starmer hail limited US-UK trade deal
content: US President Donald Trump and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Thursday announced a limited bilateral trade agreement that leaves in place Trump's 10% tariffs on British exports, modestly ...
resumen:
US President Donald Trump and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced a limited bilateral trade agreement.

The agreement leaves in place Trump's 10% tariffs on British exports, expands agricultural access for both countries, and lowers US duties on British car exports.

The deal is the first of dozens of tariff-lowering deals that Trump expects to land in coming weeks.

Trump hailed the deal in the Oval Office with Starmer on a speaker phone.

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and top trade negotiator Jamieson Greer head to Switzerland to launch negotiations with Chinese negotiators.

Trump imposed reciprocal duties of up to 50% on goods from 57 trading partners including the European Union, pausing them days later to allow time for negotiations until July 9.

He has also heaped new 25% tariffs on auto imports, ended all exemptions on steel and aluminum duties, and announced new tariff probes on pharmaceuticals, copper, lumber and semiconductors.

This week he added movies to the list.

Starmer said the announcement came nearly at the same hour 80 years ago when World War Two ended in Europe.

The two leaders heralded the plan as a "breakthrough deal" that lowers average British tariffs on US goods to 1.8% from 5.1% but keeps in place a 10% tariff on British goods.

A UK official said the deal did not include Washington's demand for restructuring of Britain's digital services tax, levied at 2% of UK revenue for online marketplaces.

Trump's first trade deal fuelled a rally on Wall Street, sending major US indexes briefly up over 1%.

The S&P 500 passenger airlines index closed up 5.4%, led by a 7.2% surge in Delta Air Lines as US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said British-made Rolls-Royce engines would enter the US duty-free.

Lutnick said Washington will roll out dozens of trade deals over the next month.

Trump's biggest challenge is resolving a virtual trade embargo between the US and China, with tariffs of 145% and 125%, respectively on each side.

Greer and Bessent will lead talks with Chinese officials in Switzerland, on Saturday and Sunday.

The British-American Business group expressed disappointment that the deal leaves in place Trump's 10% tariffs for many products, including cars.

The deal will provide potential new export opportunities for American producers worth $5 billion a year, Lutnick said, while the higher tariffs would generate $6 billion in annual US revenue.

It will reduce US tariffs on British auto imports to 10% from the current 27.5%.

The lower rate will apply to a quota of 100,000 British vehicles.

US tariffs on imports from the struggling UK steel industry will fall to zero from 25%.

Britain's 19% tariffs on US ethanol will fall to zero through a 1.4 billion-liter (370 million gallon) quota.

Both sides have agreed to new reciprocal market access on beef, with UK farmers given a first-ever tariff-free quota for 13,000 metric tonnes.

There will be no weakening of UK food standards on imports.

US beef bred with growth hormones still won't be allowed in.

US Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said the deal would "exponentially increase" US beef exports to Britain.

Details were scant on tariffs on UK pharmaceuticals imports, which could damage AstraZeneca and GSK, although a White House fact sheet said the deal would create a secure pharma supply chain.

The US agreed to give Britain preferential treatment in any further tariffs imposed under Section 232 national security investigations, which include ongoing probes of pharmaceutical and semiconductor imports.

GSK and AstraZeneca declined comment.

The UK official also welcomed Trump's assurance during the Oval Office event on finding ways to avoid his new push to tariff foreign-made movies.

Starmer's government has been seeking to build new trading relationships post-Brexit with the US, China and the EU.

The tariffs had added to the pressure on his government.

Jaguar Land Rover paused its shipments to the US for a month and the government was forced to seize control of British Steel to keep it operating.

Britain struck a free trade agreement with India this week.

title: Americans still dream about factory jobs. Can they be brought back?
content: Trump's administration said they want tariffs to boost US manufacturing, and most Americans want more factory jobs here. But what makes us nostalgic for factory work?
resumen:
President Trump's administration wants tariffs to boost US manufacturing, and most Americans want more factory jobs here.

President Trump said, "Jobs in factories will come roaring back into our country," when he announced reciprocal tariffs last month. "We will supercharge our domestic industrial base."

The American manufacturing sector has lost over a third of its workers since its peak of 19.6 million workers in 1979, now employing 12.7 million.

A poll from the Cato Institute and YouGov shows that 80% of Americans say the country would be better off if more Americans worked in manufacturing.

Jeffrey Gonzalez, associate professor of English at Montclair State University, wrote a paper about "smokestack nostalgia".

Salaries for manufacturing jobs are now in the bottom half of all jobs.

A paper by researchers at the Federal Reserve shows that the decline in unionization rates is, by and large, responsible for the drop in wages for factory work compared to other jobs.

Dylan Matthews, Vox senior correspondent, adds that some of the cultural nostalgia for factory work might stem from guilt some people might have about their "email jobs".

Republican politicians including Vice President J.D. Vance have also made national security arguments for opening more factories in the U.S. that could produce weapons.

Bernie Sanders has recently called for rebuilding American manufacturing.

Revitalizing American manufacturing was also a priority of former Presidents Biden and Obama.

There are 400,000 open positions in manufacturing as of February, according to the National Association of Manufacturers.

One new paper by Robert Z. Lawrence, Harvard's Albert L. Williams Professor of International Trade and Investment, suggests that productivity growth beats out foreign competition for the most blame for factory job losses.

As of 2023, there are 3.2 million foreign-born workers in manufacturing, about 25% of all manufacturing workers.

The last time President Trump issued import tariffs, they did not increase or decrease employment in protected sectors, according to one analysis in the National Bureau of Economic Research.

title: Opinion ‚Äì Bill Straub: Like a lemming to the sea, Andy Barr blindly follows Trump off trade war cliff
content: Plummeting cargo shipments, empty ports, declining trucking volumes, major retailers warning about empty shelves. All that and much more is the result of the inexplicable trade war ...
resumen: Plummeting cargo shipments, empty ports, declining trucking volumes, and major retailers warning about empty shelves are the result of the trade war launched by President Donald Trump over tariffs. Rep. Andy Barr, R-Lexington, supports Trump's trade war. We need the turbulence because in the long run, we‚Äôre going to have access to markets and we‚Äôre going to have less disruption and we‚Äôre going to have more free trade. Thank goodness he‚Äôs doing it because it gives us the chance to level the playing field.‚Äù Barr posted on X, ‚ÄúPresident Trump is fighting for our national interests on trade. We won‚Äôt offer countries a free ride to enter the American market when they are charging our businesses surcharges to enter theirs.‚Äô‚Äô. Nancy Qian, a professor of economics at the Kellog School of Management at Northwestern University, said, ‚ÄúTariffs this broad and at this scale haven‚Äôt really happened in modern times.‚Äô‚Äô The Wall Street Journal called the schlamassel ‚Äúthe dumbest trade war in history.‚Äô‚Äô. Trump announced plans to impose tariffs of 10 to 60 percent on dozens of America‚Äôs trading partners, with the exception of China, who ultimately drew a 145 percent levy. The moves resulted in worldwide economic upheaval, leading to panic in the bond market and a sliding U.S. dollar value. Trump temporarily suspended most of the planned tariffs to provide an opportunity to strike 90 trade deals in 90 days. Trump announced a trade framework with Britain. Trump imposed 25 percent tariffs on goods imported from Canada and Mexico. Trump once called tariff ‚Äúthe most beautiful word in the world‚Äù and sees it as a way to raise money, offsetting, perhaps, the $4.5 trillion price tag in his proposed tax cut legislation. Trump, meeting with his cabinet on April 30, is insisting a trade war is necessary to ‚Äúsave the country.‚Äù Trump said he doesn‚Äôt fear a recession after the implementation of his policies. The standoff with China has proved particularly troublesome, with the giant Asia nation announcing retaliatory tariffs, bringing the levy on most American goods to 125 percent. The US imports $433.74 billion worth of goods from China. The People‚Äôs Bank of China has taken steps to stabilize that nation‚Äôs economy and bolster financial markets. American consumers are sure to pay higher prices and face the impact of renewed inflation. Retailers who sell imported goods, and the customers who purchase them, will feel the pinch. Dock workers and truck drivers will see their jobs almost immediately imperiled. Farmers are ‚Äúalready in a full-blown crisis.‚Äù China last week cancelled its largest order of pork since the COVID crisis, revoking a 12,000-ton shipment. It also halted an order for 1,800 tons of soybeans. Consumer confidence is suffering. McDonald‚Äôs said sales in its nationwide restaurant chain fell unexpectedly in the first quarter of 2025 because customers were ‚Äúgrappling with uncertainty,‚Äù while Harley-Davidson reported a double-digit decline in sales because of consumer uncertainty. Kentucky‚Äôs $9 billion bourbon industry is facing millions of dollars in losses. Provinces in Canada are already pulling it off the shelves. Rep. Morgan McGarvey, D-Louisville, said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to lose tens of millions of dollars in bourbon sales in Ontario province alone, not to mention the whole country, because of what Trump‚Äôs policies are doing.‚Äù Churchill Downs announced it is suspending plans for a $900 million renovation because of uncertainty over economic conditions.

title: Tariffs, turbulence, and the new global order
content: The 2025 trade shock redrew economic lines. With alliances shifting, what does it mean for investors in a fractured world?
resumen:
The aggressive tariff policies announced by President Donald Trump on April 2, 2025, triggered global disruptions. The United States imposed sweeping tariffs, with China retaliating. This report analyzes the economic and market implications of this tariff escalation, including the collapse in US-China trade volumes, the re-emergence of stagflation risk, the vulnerability of multinational retailers like Walmart, and the weaponization of strategic resources like rare earth elements. It also explores the deepening cohesion of alternative economic blocs, particularly BRICS, and the increasing investment appeal of non-US equity markets, safe-haven assets, and select undervalued currencies.

President Donald Trump‚Äôs original tariffs included a baseline 10% tariff on all imports, with additional tariffs on China (34%), the European Union (20%), Japan (24%), India (26%) and Vietnam (46%). This was subsequently revised to 10% for all countries, except China, which has a 145% tariff on its exports due to its retaliation of 125% on US goods. On April 9, 2025, President Trump announced a 90-day pause on much of his Reciprocal Tariff Policy, but imposed a 10% global tariff base. These tariffs are expected to act as a substantial drag on global economic growth. The ex-ante tax hike from these tariffs amounts to nearly $1 trillion, or 3% of US GDP.

Markets reacted violently, with the S&P 500 experiencing several record-breaking intraday swings, including an 8.5% swing on April 7th. The US market experienced multiple days with swings exceeding 300 points in April 2025.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) projects global growth to slow to 2.5% in 2025, down from 3.1% in 2024. The IMF expects US GDP to grow by 1.8% in 2025. China is expected to grow at 4% this year by the IMF.

US import bookings have already fallen sharply, with container bookings from China to the US dropping by 44.49% year-over-year in the week of April 14, 2025, while the Port of Los Angeles projects a 33% year-over-year decline in import volumes for early May 2025.

China makes ~34% of all manufactured goods. President Trump believes the US can withstand the economic impact of tariffs better than China. China has downplayed the potential impact of tariffs. The US has softened its initial aggressive stance towards China. Trump has pared back his rhetoric following meetings with executives from major retailers. China has been strengthening its trade relationships with other countries.

China produces almost 70% and refines over 90% of the world's rare earth elements. Following President Trump‚Äôs tariff announcement on April 2nd, China retaliated by banning the export of REE to the US and other nations, including Japan and Germany.

Walmart's U.S. retail sales reached approximately $534 billion in 2023. Approximately 60% of its global supply chain relies on Chinese suppliers. Walmart attempted to pass on the increased costs to Chinese suppliers, demanding a 10% price cut, which was met with resistance.

US tariffs have strengthened the BRICS alliance (which includes 10 nations and 9 partner nations, representing ~55% of the world's population). BRICS foreign ministers met in Rio de Janeiro to discuss a coordinated response to US trade policies. They issued a joint statement criticizing unilateral trade measures. BRICS nations have been working together to reduce their dependence on the U.S. dollar.

A slower global economy is likely to be a headwind for global equities. The US is also at risk of stagflation. As a result, non-US global equity markets are favored. The Australian dollar and Japanese yen are significantly undervalued.

The price of gold has surged to record levels.

The 2025 tariff escalation reflects a profound realignment in global trade, economic influence, and geopolitical strategy.
