title: China, US scheduled to hold trade talks
content: CHINA and the United States are scheduled to hold official trade talks later this week, as Beijing reiterates its commitment to dialogue and cooperation while firmly safeguarding its legitimate ...
resumen:
China and the United States are scheduled to hold official trade talks later this week. Beijing reiterates its commitment to dialogue and cooperation while firmly safeguarding its legitimate interests in the face of escalating US-initiated trade tensions.

Analysts said that mounting pressure from domestic stakeholders in the US may have pushed Washington back to the negotiating table. The international community is watching closely to see whether the upcoming talks can help stabilize the global economy and provide a turning point to ease trade tensions and address trade disputes between the world's two largest economies through dialogue.

The Foreign Ministry confirmed on Wednesday that Vice-Premier He Lifeng, China's lead person for China-US economic and trade affairs, will have a meeting with the US' lead person, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, during He's visit to Switzerland from Friday to Monday. The ministry said that the talks were scheduled at the request of the US.

The conversations mark the first official public engagement between the world's two largest economies since the Trump administration's decision to impose hefty tariffs on imports from China plunged the two sides into a trade war.

Senior US officials had been signaling adjustments to tariff measures and had proactively conveyed messages through various channels, expressing their desire to engage in talks with China on tariffs and related issues, the Ministry of Commerce said on Wednesday.

A spokesperson for the ministry said, "Taking into account the global expectations, China's interests, and the calls from the US business community and consumers, China has decided to agree to engage in contact with the US."

Bessent said on Tuesday that the two sides would hold meetings on Saturday and Sunday in order to lay the groundwork for future negotiations. He told Fox News, "My sense is that this will be about de-escalation, not about the big trade deal, but we've got to de-escalate before we can move forward." He added, "The current tariffs and trade barriers are unsustainable, but we don't want to decouple."

Analysts viewed the talks more as a symbolic gesture, but it signals that the possibility of dialogue and cooperation still exists, which could pave the way for easing trade tensions and injecting much-needed certainty into global economic growth.

Robin Xing, Morgan Stanley's chief China economist, said: "We believe that both sides are hoping to reach a comprehensive agreement. The current stage of mutual escalation and tit-for-tat measures between the two countries might temporarily subside." However, due to the numerous issues involved and the considerable differences between the two sides in many areas, the negotiations will be very complex and will require a substantial amount of time to complete, Xing added.

Beijing made clear that it is entering the talks with caution. The Commerce Ministry spokesperson said, "If the US wants to talk, our door is always open, but if you say one thing and do another, or even attempt to use talks as a cover to continue coercion and extortion, China will never agree, let alone sacrifice its principled position and international fairness and justice to seek any agreement." The spokesperson stressed that negotiations must be grounded in "mutual respect, equal consultation and mutual benefit".

Cui Fan, a professor of international trade at the University of International Business and Economics in Beijing, said, "China has emerged as the most resolute, decisive and forceful among all global economies in its countermeasures against the US' protectionist actions." China has maintained a firm stance of not accepting any negotiations unless the US corrects its wrongdoings, according to Cui.

The unintended consequences of the US' unilateralism and its protectionist actions against China, such as deteriorating consumer sentiment and a record-high trade deficit, have put significant domestic pressure on the White House to find a resolution to the ongoing trade tensions.

US consumer confidence fell in April to an almost five-year low on growing pessimism about prospects for the economy and the labor market due to tariffs, decreasing nearly 8 points to 86, according to the Consumer Confidence Index released on April 29 by The Conference Board, a global think tank whose headquarters are in New York City.

Data released on Tuesday by the US Census Bureau showed that the US trade deficit ballooned 14 percent to a record $140.5 billion in March, as businesses stockpiled goods to get ahead of the sweeping tariffs that US President Donald Trump imposed in April.

Luo Zhiheng, chief economist at Yuekai Securities, said that Trump's extensive use of tariffs has severely affected the US' economic growth and damaged its international reputation, a development that Luo said will ultimately backfire on the US.

Luo said, "What China needs to do now is to turn itself into the world's largest consumer market and a core hub of global imports, filling the market gaps left by the US. As a community of shared interests, China will garner more friends ... thereby enhancing its negotiating leverage against the US."

title: Indiana's backyard fireworks are stuck in China, thanks to Trump's tariffs | Opinion
content: President Trump's tariffs are doing what Indiana lawmakers won't: curtailing fireworks.
resumen: President Trump's tariffs are curtailing fireworks. Trump's 145% tax on goods imported from China is making fireworks prohibitively expensive, just as retailers are stocking up for the July 4 holiday. Virtually all consumer fireworks come from China, and Indiana is a major recipient. Indiana's permissive posture toward fireworks costs limbs and lives while traumatizing veterans, children and animals. It's a $100 million-plus business in Indiana, which slaps a 5% fireworks sales tax on top of the regular sales tax. Independence Day is the first holiday likely to be affected by goods shortages due to Trump's tariffs. An already-dire state revenue forecast in April assumed China tariffs would be 60%, or less than half the current rate. The fireworks story ‚Äî halted shipments, lower sales ‚Äî indicates Indiana has major budget problems ahead unless Trump works out a new trade deal with China. The Times of Northwest Indiana counts 10 small fireworks stores that have already closed because they can't afford Trump's 145% tax on fireworks. Aaron Rasala of Big Bang Fireworks in Crown Point and Lowell told The Times, "The tariffs are going to drive smaller stores out of business. We have a lot of stock to offset the pricing, but the smaller mom-and-pop shops don't." Large retailers had some supplies on hand before the tariffs took effect, so there will be fireworks for sale this summer ‚Äî just not as many and likely at higher prices. Fireworks industry groups are pleading for an exemption, per NBC News.

Laptops could soon cost more than $1,000, tablets nearly $600, and smartphones nearly $1,100, while connected devices could cost up to 22 percent more. Trump's tariff regime threatens to "shrink the US economy by $69 billion annually" from price shifts of just 10 popular tech products. The CTA has been advocating on Capitol Hill for more exemptions. Consumers would lose about $16 in spending power for every $1 gained by domestic producers. The CTA is already forecasting drastic drops in consumption of video game consoles (down by up to 73 percent), laptops and tablets (45 percent), and smartphones (nearly 50 percent). For low-income families, the smartphone price hikes could hit the hardest. Apple recently estimated that tariffs could add $900 million in costs in this quarter alone. title: Entendiendo la guerra mundial de aranceles
content: La pol√≠tica arancelaria de Estados Unidos implementada por la administraci√≥n Trump desde el 2 de abril o ‚Äúd√≠a de la liberaci√≥n estadounidense‚Äù implica un cambio profundo en la l√≥gica econ√≥mica global.
resumen: La pol√≠tica arancelaria de Estados Unidos implementada por la administraci√≥n Trump desde el 2 de abril o ‚Äúd√≠a de la liberaci√≥n estadounidense‚Äù implica un cambio profundo en la l√≥gica econ√≥mica global. Stephen Miran, principal asesor econ√≥mico del presidente Trump, sostiene que el rol del d√≥lar estadounidense como moneda de reserva global ha hecho que su valor sea artificialmente alto. Esto encarecer√≠a las exportaciones del pa√≠s del norte, abaratar√≠a sus importaciones y habr√≠a debilitado a su industria manufacturera. Para contrarrestarlo, Miran propuso utilizar aranceles no solo como escudo comercial, sino como instrumentos fiscales para generar ingresos sin inflaci√≥n, disciplinarios para castigar a competidores estrat√©gicos y diplom√°ticos como condicionar el acceso al mercado estadounidense al alineamiento geopol√≠tico. Esta pol√≠tica tendr√° efectos en la econom√≠a mundial, tal como se√±ala el FMI, que ha advertido sobre los efectos globales de esta estrategia. Sus proyecciones muestran una ca√≠da de hasta 0,8 puntos porcentuales en el crecimiento mundial, un retroceso mayor en el comercio que en el PIB y un leve aumento de la inflaci√≥n. El impacto, sin embargo, ser√° desigual entre pa√≠ses, dependiendo de su exposici√≥n al comercio y su capacidad de respuesta interna. Un conjunto reciente de estudios propiciados por la Oficina Estadounidense de Investigaci√≥n Econ√≥mica (NBER por sus iniciales en ingl√©s) profundiza esta discusi√≥n con evidencia emp√≠rica y modelaci√≥n avanzada, de la mano de expertos como Iv√°n Werning del Instituto Tecnol√≥gico de Massachussets, Adrien Auclert de la Universidad de Stanford, Ludwig Straub de la Universidad de Harvard, entre varios otros acad√©micos muy destacados. Sus conclusiones son contundentes: los aranceles generan efectos contractivos en el corto plazo y reducen la productividad y el bienestar en el largo. Adem√°s, lejos de corregir los d√©ficits comerciales, tienden a redistribuir ineficientemente el gasto, afectando la inversi√≥n y el consumo. En ausencia de una respuesta coordinada, las ganancias transitorias en el comercio se disipan r√°pidamente ante las represalias externas. Incluso en t√©rminos fiscales, su eficiencia es limitada salvo bajo condiciones muy espec√≠ficas. De forma m√°s contundente, Maurice Obstfeld, execonomista jefe del FMI, se√±ala que el d√©ficit comercial estadounidense no se debe a tratados desventajosos, sino a un problema dom√©stico: EE. UU. ahorra menos de lo que invierte. En este contexto, cualquier intento de reducir el d√©ficit mediante aranceles est√° condenado al fracaso si no se corrige el desequilibrio macroecon√≥mico interno. Seg√∫n el Instituto Peterson para la Econom√≠a Internacional, el comercio global ya no se define por la eficiencia, sino por la l√≥gica de bloques y la disputa por el poder. Las cadenas globales de valor se est√°n reconfigurando en funci√≥n de alianzas estrat√©gicas, y el acceso a mercados se vuelve una herramienta de presi√≥n pol√≠tica. Las empresas no pueden seguir operando bajo los supuestos de la globalizaci√≥n cl√°sica. El reconocido centro de pensamiento McKinsey sugiere crear unidades de inteligencia geopol√≠tica para anticipar riesgos y redise√±ar las redes de suministro. Por su parte, la Revista de Negocios de Harvard recomienda medidas pr√°cticas: asegurar trazabilidad de insumos, evaluar costos entre relocalizaci√≥n y aranceles, y redirigir estrategias comerciales en funci√≥n de bloques pol√≠ticos, no solo econ√≥micos. Bolivia se ver√° afectada por el encarecimiento de insumos, las trabas al comercio y los cambios en el acceso a tecnolog√≠a o financiamiento.

title: What to know about the Fed‚Äôs decision.
content: The Federal Reserve stuck to a wait-and-see approach as officials brace for President Trump‚Äôs tariffs to stoke higher inflation and slower growth. Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said that it‚Äôs ‚Äúnot ...
resumen: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged for a third meeting in a row on Wednesday, sticking to a wait-and-see approach amid uncertainty about how significantly President Trump‚Äôs tariffs will raise inflation and slow growth. The unanimous decision to stand pat will keep interest rates at 4.25 percent to 4.5 percent. Rates have been there since December after a series of cuts in the second half of 2024. The Fed acknowledged that the labor market was still ‚Äúsolid.‚Äù But policymakers also noted that ‚Äúuncertainty about the economic outlook has increased further‚Äù and ‚Äúrisks of higher unemployment and higher inflation have risen.‚Äù Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said he could not yet say ‚Äúwhich way this will shake out‚Äù in terms of whether to be more worried about inflation or growth. He later captured the uncertainty of the moment, saying ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really not at all clear what it is we should do.‚Äù A 10 percent universal tariff remains in place, along with additional levies on steel, aluminum and cars. The president has also imposed a minimum tariff of 145 percent on Chinese goods. The whiplash has unnerved financial markets, stoking volatility as Wall Street digested the various twists and turns associated with Mr. Trump‚Äôs trade policy and his subsequent attacks on Mr. Powell for ignoring his demands to lower interest rates. The central bank is struggling to both assess the economic fallout from Mr. Trump‚Äôs policies and game out how it will set monetary policy in an environment in which its goals of maintaining a healthy labor market and keeping inflation low and stable may be in conflict. Officials have grown increasingly worried about how much Mr. Trump‚Äôs policies, which also include slashing spending and deporting immigrants, will sap growth. The fear is that the uncertainty will further chill business activity. The Fed is not in a position to respond to early signs that the economy is weakening by preemptively lowering interest rates because of inflation. Market-based measures of inflation expectations suggest that inflation will indeed remain contained after an initial pop. The bar for the central bank to lower interest rates is higher this time. Officials will most likely need to see tangible evidence that the labor market is beginning to weaken before restarting cuts. If monthly jobs growth grinds to a halt, or turns negative, and layoffs rise, that could be enough to bolster the central bank‚Äôs conviction that it can begin to reduce rates. Powell said the Fed is not in a hurry to lower interest rates and is going to wait to see the economic effects from Trump‚Äôs tariffs before taking any action. With the economy still on solid footing and unemployment low, Fed Chair Powell made clear that there is ‚Äúno cost‚Äù to the Fed taking its time. Powell leaned into the uncertainty of the moment both in terms of how Trump‚Äôs tariffs will impact the economy and also how the Fed should react. Powell reiterated that it would be a ‚Äúdifficult judgment‚Äù if faced with a situation in which the Fed‚Äôs goals of maintaining a healthy labor market and low inflation clash. Powell said the Fed‚Äôs policy settings are still restrictive and emphasizes that the Fed is not in a hurry to take action. Powell said the Fed can‚Äôt yet say ‚Äúwhich way this will shake out‚Äù in terms of whether to be more worried about inflation or growth. Powell notes that whether or not tariffs translate into more persistent inflation depends on whether inflation expectations remain ‚Äúanchored‚Äù ‚Äî that is, whether people expect prices to keep rising. President Trump has been publicly pressuring Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, to lower the rate the central bank controls.

title: China Agreed to U.S. Tariff Talks but Is Likely to Play Hardball
content: Beijing says it will meet with American officials to discuss trade, but warned Washington against using the engagement to ratchet up pressure on China.
resumen:
China is seeking to cast itself as the responsible one in a bruising superpower competition by agreeing to meet with the Trump administration to discuss trade.

China had publicly said that it would not engage in trade talks with the United States under duress, refusing to ‚Äúkneel down‚Äù and compromise with a ‚Äúbully.‚Äù It insisted that Washington should first drop its eye-watering tariffs on China as a condition for negotiations.

Beijing indicated it would come to the table after all, saying that its top trade official, He Lifeng, would meet with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent in Switzerland this week. It maintained a tough stance, warning Washington against using the talks as ‚Äúa smoke screen to continue coercion and extortion.‚Äù

The Chinese government said it had come to this decision ‚Äúbased on a full consideration of global expectations, China‚Äôs interests and the calls of American industry and consumers.‚Äù

Yun Sun, a China analyst at the Stimson Center, said, ‚ÄúChina is trying to frame itself as the responsible party, but it‚Äôs still a pretty hard-line tone: You better behave yourself in these talks.‚Äù

Economic data has shown that the trade brinkmanship was taking a toll on both countries‚Äô economies.

The Trump administration‚Äôs decision to raise tariffs on Chinese goods imported to the United States by 145 percent, and China‚Äôs response in hiking its own tariffs on American goods to 125 percent, has effectively frozen all trade between the two countries in recent weeks.

Chinese factories were hit with the steepest slowdown in activity in more than a year, and shipments of Chinese goods to the United States have plunged, triggering a wave of warnings from retailers about shortages. The American economy shrank in the first three months of the year, and companies slashed growth forecasts.

Mr. Bessent said the talks with China were more likely to be aimed at de-escalating trade tensions than reaching a deal.

Mr. Bessent said he expected the meeting with Chinese officials in Switzerland to focus on de-escalation rather than any major deal.

China wants to show that it will be coming to the negotiations from a position of strength, even though the U.S. had not canceled tariffs first as Beijing had demanded. In recent days it has repeatedly said that U.S. officials had reached out for talks and that it was considering the request.

Ms. Sun said, ‚ÄúThe Chinese are trying to avoid the image that the Chinese were eager to talk.‚Äù

Chinese officials will likely be treating the trade talks as a fact-finding mission.

Wang Xiangwei, an associate professor of journalism at Hong Kong Baptist University, said, ‚ÄúThe Chinese want to find out what Donald Trump is really up to, and you can only get this by engaging in direct talks.‚Äù

Peter Navarro, a senior White House trade adviser, has defended the tariffs as necessary, while Mr. Bessent has said the U.S. is willing to negotiate with countries.

Mr. Bessent said on Fox News that the talks would be held on Saturday and Sunday.

China said Mr. He was going to be in Geneva from Friday to Monday for meetings with Swiss leaders and that while he was there he would also meet Mr. Bessent. The Trump administration said Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, would also attend the meetings, though China did not mention Mr. Greer in its own statements about the talks.

China has also been trying to persuade other countries not to cave to pressure from the Trump administration‚Äôs efforts to isolate China by imposing tariffs of their own on Chinese products, or by decoupling from Chinese manufacturing.

Chinese officials have been under pressure at home from the fallout of both a multiyear property crisis that has wiped out the savings of many families, along with broader trade tensions with countries other than the United States.

China‚Äôs central bank and its financial regulators on Wednesday took their biggest policy steps yet to shield the economy from the trade war, moving to shore up the economy with a series of steps to make it easier for banks to lend money and get people spending.

Wu Qing, China‚Äôs stock regulator, said, ‚ÄúThe Trump administration‚Äôs ‚Äútariff policies have dealt a severe blow to the international economic and trade order, triggered significant turbulence in international financial markets, and placed considerable pressure on the domestic capital market.‚Äù

The Chinese side also comes to the talks emboldened by the knowledge that Mr. Trump has blinked in the face of a sharp sell-off in U.S. government bond markets, and broader financial market turbulence. The midterm elections in the United States could exert some pressure on Mr. Trump to lower or cut tariffs if consumer prices rise as a result of a shortage of goods.

Scott Kennedy, a senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said, ‚ÄúIf they totally stonewall the Trump administration, they could end up looking complicit in bringing the global economy to a halt.‚Äù

content: The trade war is costing Austin half his paycheck, he said. According to the Canadian Trucking Alliance, Canadian trucks move about 80% to 90% of American exports to the country. The CTA surveyed its ...
resumen:
Canadian truckers are seeing big drop-offs in cross-border traffic, from the automotive and agriculture sectors.

Steve Austin has been driving trucks for nearly five decades.

Steve Austin said, ‚Äúbusiness is really, really slow.‚Äù He has had a couple three-day weeks, and the days he's working six, seven [hour] days. He's used to 11- to 12-hour days. It really is hurting.

The CTA surveyed its 5,000 members about the impact of the trade war so far.

Stephen Laskowski, the CTA‚Äôs president and CEO, said about 10% to 15% of their members have already laid people off, meaning that there's no freight to move, and well over 30% to 40% are saying they're close to laying people off.

There was an initial boost in business when the president announced his tariffs and businesses tried to stock up before the new taxes hit, Laskowski said. Now, their members are sitting and waiting for calls. There is little demand right now in a lot of sectors, so a lot of trucks are sitting.

Truckers are seeing big drop-offs in traffic, from the automotive and agriculture sectors. But hauling Canadian goods within Canada is holding up a little better.

Dale Johnstone said his business slowed down a bit at the start of the trade war. Now, moving mixed freight between the Greater Toronto Area and Central Ontario, ‚Äúactually, I'm pretty busy. I got a full load that I got to get back up to central Ontario with this afternoon and get it unloaded.‚Äù

title: Avoiding a world trade war
content: We are on the precipice of a world trade war ‚Äî active and strategic economic diplomacy will be needed to avoid it.
resumen:
The threat of a world trade war due to retaliatory tariffs places the global economic system at risk, while challenging the continuation of a rules-based system and encouraging potentially damaging trade deals. To preserve an open, rules-based system amidst this uncertainty, collective action is needed, led by East Asia and Europe, exemplified by ASEAN's coordinated, non-retaliatory response and continued commitment to multilateral trade norms.

The 28 per cent average tariff rate in the United States today is significantly higher than the average rate of 19.8 per cent imposed during the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930. The highest Smoot-Hawley tariff rate was 59.1 per cent, well below the 145 per cent US President Donald Trump has slapped on all Chinese imports. Today‚Äôs tariffs return the United States to its 1821 to 1900 average 29.7 per cent tariff rate.

The retaliatory spiral provoked by the Smoot-Hawley tariffs led to the collapse of global trade from 1929‚Äì33, and gave rise to geopolitical tension that brought the World War II several years after. Tariff contagion like that is what‚Äôs at risk today: we are on the precipice of a world trade war. Active and strategic economic diplomacy will be needed to avoid that.

The global response to Trump‚Äôs Liberation Day tariffs has thus far been, except for China, Canada and Europe, restraint. Europe has temporarily backed away from retaliation because of Trump‚Äôs 90 day tariff pause. But more uncertainty is on the way and other countries will be pressured into retaliating like the Chinese and Europeans, do damaging deals with the United States, or join the protectionist game.

The world is about to be rocked by huge flows of trade that are diverted from the United States as well as volatile hot money capital flows, big currency swings and macroeconomic shocks. As Chinese goods face a prohibitive 145 per cent tariff entering the United States, it is likely those products would be flowing other markets.

Chinese products hitting global markets will improve living standards and will relieve inflationary pressures in many countries. But those that compete directly with producing those goods will be tempted to ‚Äòprotect‚Äô themselves from what they will see as the dumping of goods on international markets. Tariffs on imports will be the easiest tool for governments to reach for. They are contagious.

The United States has turned its back on the rules-based economic order of which it was the creator and which it underpinned in the post-war era. But the rest of the world does not need to let Trump tear the whole system down. The era of US leadership may be over but the rest of the world has an interest in preserving the global trade order and avoiding a ‚Äòmight-is-right‚Äô world of economic disorder. The United States might be the world‚Äôs largest economy in market exchange rates and its largest consumer but it now only accounts for 11 per cent of global trade.

What is needed is collective action led by East Asia and Europe ‚Äî where trade openness is an economic and political security imperative ‚Äî not against the United States, but to retain the global public good of an open, rules-based economic system.

The response from Southeast Asia has so far been the benchmark. Leaders of ASEAN‚Äôs most important economies ‚Äî Indonesia‚Äôs President Prabowo Subianto, Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, Philippines President Bongbong Marcos and Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong ‚Äî have coordinated closely around a non-retaliatory response. ASEAN Economic Ministers had already agreed in February to cooperate in the face of looming US tariffs and to avoid protectionist measures against surges of Chinese imports locked out of the US market. The ministers convened a special meeting after the US tariffs were announced and created a taskforce to monitor developments and coordinate collective responses. An ASEAN Leaders‚Äô Meeting has been called for early May. The risks for ASEAN are existential and ASEAN Leaders‚Äô strategy at that point will be globally consequential.

Days before Trump‚Äôs Liberation Day tariffs were announced, China, Japan and South Korea‚Äôs trade ministers agreed to cooperate on trade and cited East Asia‚Äôs Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), that ASEAN created and drives, as a platform from which to do so. ASEAN could call for an ASEAN+3 Leaders‚Äô Meeting with Northeast Asia like they did at the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic. But RCEP with Australia and New Zealand would have a better chance of bolstering connections to other Europe and global initiatives. RCEP is the natural platform for projecting and protecting East Asia‚Äôs trade and economic interests.

Collective action to preserve the multilateral trading system should come as a priority despite countries negotiating their own deals with the United States. Japan was first in line with Trump himself joining the negotiators last week. The world will be watching closely for Japanese appeasement ‚Äî moving to managed trade, having the US security blanket contingent on increased purchase and having to boost its defence spending. Bilateral deals with the White House cannot come at the expense of broader interests without triggering multilateral meltdown.

Will any deal struck with this White House, even if it is possible to strike one, be faithfully honoured given the United States has now effectively invalidated every free trade agreement it has ever signed?

The Indonesian delegation led by Economic Minister Airlangga Hartanto successfully met the United States Trade Representative and Secretary of Commerce, but still has no guarantee to receive favourable deal from the United States, even when Indonesia offered various concessions, including to increase imports from the country. As part of reform process, Indonesia seems willing to remove costly local-content requirements and other protectionist measures. But granting US imports preferential access over other imports and granting US companies monopoly power in Indonesian markets will not only be economically damaging, it is seen domestically as political capitulation to a bully. Reforms need to be consistent with the bedrock principle of the multilateral trading system: most-favoured nation or equal treatment.

Southeast Asia‚Äôs multilateralist instincts and norms have resulted in the right kind of initial strategic, cooperative reaction. It‚Äôs the next step, in negotiating a multilateral course around Trump, that will be decisive to global outcomes.

title: Fed holds rates steady, warns of stagflation risks
content: Fed officials opted Wednesday to hold interest rates steady as President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs unsettle the US economy.
resumen: The Federal Reserve (Fed) decided to hold its benchmark interest rate steady, keeping it at a range of 4.25% to 4.5%. The Fed's statement included a warning about rising risks of higher unemployment and higher inflation, signaling concerns about stagflation. The Fed is monitoring the economic impact of President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that the Fed does not need to rush to adjust rates and that there is a "great deal of uncertainty" about the implications of Trump‚Äôs tariff policy. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note edged lower to 4.28%. The US dollar slightly strengthened against other major currencies. Traders expect a 76.8% chance the Fed holds rates steady again at its next decision in June. Powell said the outcome of trade talks could "materially" change the economic picture. Powell said the Fed has limited tools to address supply chain problems. Powell declined to say the Fed will lower rates this year, blaming Trump's tariffs. Powell said the central bank may have been ‚Äúa little late‚Äù to begin lowering rates. The Federal Reserve received criticism for waiting until September‚Äôs monetary policy meeting last year to begin cutting interest rates for the first time since 2020. The Federal Reserve‚Äôs latest policy statement noted that the risk of higher unemployment and higher inflation have both risen. The Fed‚Äôs decision to keep rates unchanged for the third meeting in a row was unanimous. The US economy is beginning to show the effects of President Donald Trump‚Äôs haphazard trade war. The Dow closed higher by 285 points, or 0.7%. The S&P 500 gained 0.43%. The Nasdaq Composite gained 0.27%. Consumer sentiment is falling, and businesses are concerned about hiring and investing due to tariffs. The Federal Reserve is in a bind with concerns about inflation and an economic slump, which will lead to higher unemployment. President Donald Trump signaled that the 145% tariff he placed on most imports from China is here to stay. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said some of the 18 trade deals being considered are in ‚Äúquite advanced‚Äù stages. The unemployment rate in April held steady at 4.2% and employers added a surprisingly strong 177,000 new jobs. The Federal Reserve is widely expected to announce Wednesday it is keeping interest rates unchanged for the third time in a row.

title: Trump‚Äôs Threatened Tariffs Are So Large, 10% Feels Like a Relief
content: The statement refers to the 10 percent tariff that Mr. Trump put in place on most U.S. imports one month ago. Such a significant increase in U.S. tariffs would have been unthinkable a few years ago.
resumen:
There has been a mantra spreading among weary corporate executives: Ten percent is the new zero.

The statement refers to the 10 percent tariff that Mr. Trump put in place on most U.S. imports one month ago.

Mr. Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù announcement on April 2 that he was planning tariffs of 10 percent to 60 percent on dozens of America‚Äôs trading partners set off a rout in the bond markets and a flight from the U.S. dollar.

Mr. Trump also ratcheted up tariffs on China to a minimum of 145 percent amid a trade spat with Beijing.

The president quickly paused tariffs on most countries, giving them 90 days to negotiate trade deals instead.

Mr. Trump also granted a lucrative exemption from China tariffs for makers of electronics and offered some limited relief for automakers.

Investors have lapped up any signs of good news.

Stock markets have now regained nearly all of the losses they sustained after April 2.

The United States still has a 10 percent ‚Äúuniversal‚Äù tariff in effect on most imports globally, as well as 25 percent tariffs on imported cars, metals and goods from Canada and Mexico.

Overall, according to the Budget Lab at Yale, consumers face an average effective tariff rate of 28 percent, the highest since 1901.

For some companies, tariffs of 10 to 25 percent are still enough to erase profit margins, stall expansion or hiring plans or even push them out of business.

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has warned that many small businesses in particular might not survive.

Jane Fraser, the chief executive of Citigroup, said companies could withstand lower tariffs, though trade uncertainty had forced them to pause investment and hiring.

Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, and Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, would meet with Chinese officials this weekend in Geneva.

The administration might choose to quickly drop some of its tariffs on China as a good-will gesture once the countries restart negotiations ‚Äî but tariffs have risen so much that the United States might have to cut them by more than 100 percentage points to meaningfully restart trade.

In a post on Truth Social on Sunday, Mr. Trump proposed adding 100 percent tariffs to movies produced outside the country.

On Monday, the president said that tariffs on pharmaceuticals would be coming in the next few weeks and that he had already decided on the rate.

Maros Sefcovic, the European Union‚Äôs commissioner for trade, said that ‚Äúmore U.S. tariff actions could well be on their way,‚Äù pointing to investigations into lumber, pharmaceuticals, semiconductors, critical minerals and trucks.

If all those investigations led to tariffs, he said, 97 percent of E.U. exports to the United States would be subject to taxes.

In an interview with NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúMeet the Press‚Äù broadcast on Sunday, Mr. Trump insisted that he would preserve the threat of tariffs, no matter what.

En respuesta a las recientes medidas proteccionistas impuestas por el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump, el Mercado Com√∫n del Sur (Mercosur) anunci√≥ este viernes la ampliaci√≥n temporal de su lista de productos exceptuados del Arancel Externo Com√∫n (AEC), con el objetivo de mitigar el impacto negativo en el comercio exterior regional.

En el encuentro participaron el canciller argentino Gerardo Werthein, junto con sus hom√≥logos Mauro Vieira (Brasil), Celinda Sosa Lunda (Bolivia), Mario Lubetkin (Uruguay) y Rub√©n Ram√≠rez (Paraguay).

En un comunicado conjunto, los cancilleres subrayaron ‚Äúel consenso alcanzado‚Äù para aumentar la cantidad de productos exceptuados del AEC, pasando de 100 a 150 √≠tems. Esta medida busca otorgar mayor flexibilidad a los pa√≠ses miembro para sortear los efectos de la reciente pol√≠tica comercial estadounidense, que incluye un aumento de 10 puntos porcentuales en los aranceles a productos sudamericanos.

Fuentes del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de Argentina explicaron que la medida permitir√° ‚Äúsuavizar el impacto del incremento arancelario estadounidense y negociar condiciones m√°s favorables con Washington‚Äù, en un contexto global marcado por tensiones comerciales crecientes.

Adem√°s de la flexibilizaci√≥n arancelaria, los ministros reafirmaron su compromiso de ‚Äúpriorizar e impulsar negociaciones externas con pa√≠ses comercialmente relevantes para todos los socios durante el segundo semestre del corriente a√±o‚Äù. En este sentido, las miradas tambi√©n est√°n puestas en la conclusi√≥n del acuerdo entre el Mercosur y la Uni√≥n Europea (UE), cuyas negociaciones han cobrado nuevo impulso.

content: President Donald Trump‚Äôs faith in tariffs is undimmed by a dose of negative US growth and signs of a looming supply crunch.
resumen: President Donald Trump's lifelong belief that tariffs can make the United States richer by forcing other nations to bend to his demands is being reinforced by the early skirmishes in his trade wars. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will meet with Chinese officials this weekend in Switzerland. The talks, which will also include US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer, represent the most critical moment in the trade wars so far. Trump‚Äôs strategy and rhetoric in recent days are likely to complicate Bessent‚Äôs assignment, since the president is showing that his faith in tariffs is undimmed by a dose of negative US growth and signs of a looming supply crunch. Trump said of Chinese leaders in the Oval Office on Tuesday, ‚ÄúThey want to meet‚Ä¶ by not trading, we‚Äôre losing nothing.‚Äù Trump‚Äôs statements suggest that tariffs may not be the means to an end, but the end itself. The administration has yet to announce any new breakthroughs, so there is no real prospect of tariffs being lifted any time soon. Trump‚Äôs volatility and record of changing his mind on a dime mean that none of his statements should ever be regarded as definitive. The talks with China will be key to establishing whether a soft landing is possible for the trade wars. Bessent told Fox News on Tuesday that his initial plan is to try to cool the confrontation and that the talks with Chinese officials represent the ‚Äúmissing piece‚Äù in the administration‚Äôs strategy. China typically favors intricate trade talks that play out for months. A growing number of Trump‚Äôs comments and social media posts suggest that he‚Äôs not yet interested in changing course a third of the way through a 90-day pause in reciprocal tariffs. On Tuesday, he played down expectations for a flurry of trade deals that he and senior aides had been predicting were imminent for days. Trump said, ‚ÄúSo, I wish they‚Äôd keep ‚Äî you know, stop asking, ‚ÄòHow many deals are you signing this week?‚Äô Because one day, we‚Äôll come and we‚Äôll give you a hundred deals.‚Äù Trump‚Äôs preferred outcome of the trade deals may be permanent protectionism. Trump explained his vision of operating as a retailer who sets the price for each individual customer. In this scenario, tariffs are not an attempt to draw countries into talks to unlock acceptable deals for both sides. Instead, they are a way to fix a levy for the right to do business with the US that would depend on how far each nation sacrifices their own economic interests to boost America‚Äôs. Trump said, ‚ÄúThink of us as a super-luxury store, a store that has the goods. You‚Äôre going to come and you‚Äôre going to pay a price, and we‚Äôre going to give you a very good price.‚Äù Trump also said last month that his 145% tariff on China will ‚Äúcome down come down substantially, but it won‚Äôt be zero.‚Äù He told Time Magazine in a recent interview that he‚Äôd consider it a ‚Äútotal victory‚Äù if tariffs are at 50%. The days of untamed globalization are over. He wants to transform it so that the US becomes a manufacturing and exporting giant but doesn‚Äôt buy things from abroad. Trump said, ‚ÄúThey have to sign deals with us‚Ä¶ We don‚Äôt care about their market. They want a piece of our market.‚Äù Trump‚Äôs comments on trade alongside Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney offered a striking glimpse into how he thinks. Having a president set the price of access to the US market would be an extraordinary way to run a 21st-century economy. Trump has a foggy understanding of how tariffs work. Attempts to artificially control the price of goods usually causes shortages and supply chain issues, and they can spike inflation. Trump has already granted temporary tariffs carve-outs on some tech products, including iPhones, and to parts manufacturers that supply the auto industry after lobbying from CEOs. Trump said Tuesday, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want steel from Canada ‚Äòcause we‚Äôre making our own steel‚Ä¶ We really don‚Äôt want Canadian steel and we don‚Äôt want Canadian aluminum and various other things because we want to be able to do it ourself.‚Äù Trump is envisioning a real attempt to drive other nations out of business to make them dependent on America. Trump said, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt really want cars from Canada. And we‚Äôve put tariffs on cars from Canada, and at a certain point, it won‚Äôt make economic sense for Canada to build those cars.‚Äù Trump said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been ripped off by everybody for 50 years, for 50 years, and we‚Äôre just not going to do that anymore. We can‚Äôt do that, and we can‚Äôt let any country do that to us.‚Äù

title: EJ ANTONI: Trump‚Äôs Labor Market Is Healthy, But There Are Warnings Signs
content: While the mainstream media talking heads pontificate about Trump‚Äôs economy being in freefall, the labor market just keeps moving along.
resumen: The April jobs report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows solid growth, with 177,000 payrolls added, though previous months were revised down to 119,000 additional payrolls. title: Trump Officials to Meet With Chinese Counterparts Amid Trade Standoff
content: Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, and Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, will discuss trade and economic matters with the officials this week.
resumen:
Top officials from the Trump administration will meet with their Chinese counterparts in Switzerland this week, the first formal meeting about trade between the United States and China since President Trump raised tariffs on Chinese imports to triple-digit levels last month.

Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, and Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, plan to meet with Chinese officials during a trip to Geneva, where they will discuss trade and economic matters.

He Lifeng, the vice premier for economic policy, would visit Switzerland from Friday to Monday and hold talks with Mr. Bessent. Mr. Bessent said on Fox News that the talks would be held on Saturday and Sunday.

In early April, Mr. Trump escalated tariffs on Chinese exports to a minimum of 145 percent.

The Trump administration has criticized China for its role in bringing fentanyl and ingredients to make the drug to the United States, as well as a bevy of unfair trade practices. Mr. Trump and his advisers have also censured China for failing to stick to the terms of a trade deal the president negotiated in his first term. China, in return, has called Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs ‚Äúillegal and unreasonable.‚Äù

In the first quarter of this year, the U.S. share of imported goods from China fell to its lowest level in more than two decades.

Mr. Trump said the Chinese were eager for a meeting.

A spokesperson for the Chinese Ministry of Commerce said that U.S. officials had ‚Äúcontinuously leaked information about adjusting tariff measures and actively conveyed information to China through various channels, hoping to talk with China on tariffs and other issues.‚Äù

‚ÄúChina has carefully evaluated the U.S. information,‚Äù the spokesperson said. ‚ÄúOn the basis of fully considering global expectations, China‚Äôs interests and the calls of the U.S. industry and consumers, China has decided to agree to engage with the U.S.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf the United States wants to resolve the issue through negotiations,‚Äù the spokesperson added, ‚Äúit must face up to the serious negative impact of unilateral tariff measures on itself and the world, face up to international economic and trade rules, fairness and justice, and rational voices from all walks of life, show sincerity in talks, correct its wrong practices, meet China halfway and resolve the concerns of both sides through equal consultation.‚Äù

Mr. Bessent and Mr. Greer are also expected to meet with the Swiss president, Karin Keller-Sutter, to discuss a potential trade deal.

Eswar Prasad, a former official at the International Monetary Fund who is now an economics professor at Cornell University, said that it was a ‚Äúhugely positive development that the two sides are finally setting aside their posturing and commencing negotiations.‚Äù

content: The businesses that rely on goods moving through California‚Äôs ports are about to feel the pain of Trump‚Äôs trade war.

American manufacturers and retailers are anticipating a sharp drop-off in imports from China this week as they struggle to pay a 145 percent tariff on goods from the country.

Dozens of ships have canceled planned arrivals at West Coast ports.

Stephen Cheung, CEO of the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corp., says nobody is safe from the global economic upheaval.

The climate world ‚Äî especially in the transportation and energy storage sectors that rely on lithium batteries ‚Äî is particularly vulnerable to the pain.

title: US electric vehicle market amid trade and policy uncertainty
content: US President Trump recently imposed a 145% tariff on Chinese goods, which include electric vehicle (EV) components.
resumen: The US EV market is facing uncertainty due to trade and policy shifts. Both the Biden and Trump administrations aimed to reduce reliance on Chinese-made vehicles, but their strategies differ. The ongoing US-China trade war is negatively impacting the US EV market, particularly due to dependence on Chinese imports like lithium-ion batteries. US EV manufacturers struggle to compete with cost-competitive Chinese EVs. Trump's broader rollback of EV-friendly policies poses a threat to future domestic sales. In 2024, the Biden administration imposed a 100% tariff on Chinese EVs and a 25% tariff on lithium-ion EV batteries. The Biden administration set a goal that 50% of all new vehicles sold in the US by 2030 would be battery electric vehicles (BEVs). The Biden Administration focused on infrastructure development, allocating $5bn under the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure (NEVI) Formula Program to build a nationwide network of 500,000 high-speed EV charging stations by 2030, and strengthening the domestic battery manufacturing sector. In September 2024, the US DoE announced over $3bn in funding for 25 projects across 14 states. Trump recently imposed a 145% tariff on Chinese goods, including EV components. China controls around 60% of global rare earth elements (REE) mining and 90% of its processing. US-built vehicles rely heavily on international supply chains. Tesla imports 20% to 25% of its components from other countries. Tesla‚Äôs stock has fallen nearly 50% from its December 2024 peak. BYD surpassed Tesla in global EV sales in Q4 2024, delivering 594,839 units, versus Tesla‚Äôs 491,062. The imposition of tariffs has led to diplomatic friction. The Trump administration has granted temporary exemptions for certain automakers. In March 2025, it issued a one-month reprieve from tariffs for companies including Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis. On April 29, Trump suggested he would ease tariffs affecting car production costs. Tesla has made major investments in lithium-ion battery production at its Gigafactory in Nevada. The US is ramping up domestic battery production, ranking second globally with 91 lithium-ion EV battery plants due to come online between 2025 and 2032. China has over 277 upcoming lithium-ion battery plants set to reach completion between 2025 and 2032. Plans to ease fuel economy and CO‚ÇÇ reduction targets would reduce the pressure on automakers to invest in electrification technologies. The administration‚Äôs intent to eliminate the $7,500 federal EV tax credit could drastically reduce EV demand. Several battery investments have already been delayed or canceled, including LG‚Äôs Queen Creek plant in Arizona and the HL-GA Battery Company plant in Georgia.

title: Strategic Opportunities: How Does Putin Benefit from Trump‚Äôs Presence in the White House?
content: The presence of U.S. President Donald Trump in the White House may represent a golden opportunity for Russia to achieve its strategic interests, both ...
resumen:
The presence of U.S. President Donald Trump in the White House may represent a golden opportunity for Russia to achieve its strategic interests, both in its immediate regional surroundings and in seeking to restore part of its lost role on the global stage. This arises from both presidents speaking the same language of ‚Äúinterests,‚Äù which explains their political behavior and motivations for foreign action, alongside direct interests for Moscow under Trump‚Äôs administration, contrasting with his predecessor, President Joe Biden, who sought to isolate Russia after its war on Ukraine in February 2022. Russia‚Äôs vision of its role cannot be viewed in isolation from the realization of its declining comprehensive capabilities compared to both the United States and China, and its practical inability to exercise that role, as reflected in its weakened economy and the depletion of its military machinery after nearly three years of continuous fighting.

Trump and Putin share traits that characterize their self-perception, the status of their countries, and the global order, including ‚ÄúOver-leadership‚Äù with Contextual Differences, Nationalism as a Major Driving Force for Foreign Policy, and A Diminished View of Multilateral International Institutions. These personal traits create space for a ‚Äúpsychological convergence‚Äù that allows Trump and Putin to operate in a manner highlighted by Trump‚Äôs opening of back channels for understanding with his Russian counterpart and sending his personal envoy, Steve Witkoff, to meet with Putin four times between January and April 2025, with the Russian president welcoming these meetings. Yuri Ushakov, Putin‚Äôs assistant for foreign policy, described these meetings as ‚Äúuseful and constructive.‚Äù Trump and Putin differ in the depth of their strategic thinking and movement on the global chessboard. While Trump prefers to rely on ‚Äúdeals‚Äù rather than ‚Äúideology‚Äù or ‚Äúlong-term strategies‚Äù to achieve gains, stemming from his background as a successful businessman; Putin operates according to a specific strategy focused on rapid gains with an emphasis on long-term goals, which include addressing the root causes of the conflict in Ukraine, obstructing NATO‚Äôs expansion near Russian borders, and reshaping the global order so that Russia plays a significant role in it, especially concerning Europe, which Moscow considers its main sphere of influence.

Russia‚Äôs interests under Trump‚Äôs administration can be summarized as follows: Neutralizing Ukraine According to Putin‚Äôs Ideological Vision, which primarily hinges on recognition of Moscow‚Äôs sovereignty over Crimea, occupied in 2014, retaining territories occupied in Eastern Ukraine since the onset of the war in 2022, including Luhansk Oblast and parts of Donetsk, Kherson, and Zaporizhzhia. Halting NATO‚Äôs Expansion Along Russian Borders. Lifting Sanctions Imposed on the Russian Economy Since 2014.

Moscow sees many opportunities presented by Trump‚Äôs presence in the White House, allowing for a greater ability to pursue an influential global role, as follows: Trump‚Äôs Policies and the Fracture of the Western Deterrence Camp, Undermining the International Order Led by Washington, and Reshaping Global Geopolitical Balances to Expand Russia‚Äôs Influence. Moscow is betting on two main factors to achieve this goal: the impact of Trump‚Äôs presence and the U.S. focus on countering the Chinese threat. Russia has worked to enhance its image as an independent power from the West and sought to strengthen its strategic alliances, foremost among them its relationship with China, and has worked to bolster its relations with North Korea. Additionally, Russia has sought to form new alliances with countries like India, and has not overlooked building partnerships with countries in Africa and Latin America. The competition with Washington over the rich oil and gas resources of the Arctic cannot be ignored, where Russia controls nearly half the region‚Äôs reserves.

The aforementioned opportunities face several challenges that affect Russia‚Äôs effectiveness in fulfilling the role it aspires to, especially when compared to the United States and China. Russia is suffering from a decline in its capabilities, as evidenced by the weakness of its industrial base compared to major European countries like Germany and France, as well as its economy‚Äôs reliance on exporting oil and gas. The Russian army‚Äôs inability to decisively conclude the war in Ukraine. These challenges are connected to the unintended consequences of the rift in U.S.-European relations, which has prompted Europe to rearm itself, as highlighted by the EU representatives‚Äô agreement at a summit held for this purpose in Brussels in March 2025 to mobilize about 800 billion euros for European rearmament. Russia‚Äôs continued ambition for a global role hinges on two main factors: Putin‚Äôs continued rule and Moscow‚Äôs ability to overcome the challenges resulting from its increasing dependence on China and North Korea to offset its losses in the Ukrainian war, along with facing Western sanctions.

Russia recognizes that Trump‚Äôs return to the White House opens a rare strategic window for repositioning itself in the international system and achieving several of its vital interests, both in Ukraine and in reshaping global balances.

title: How will Canada‚Äôs new prime minister affect New York?

resumen:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has a mandate to fight back against the Trump administration‚Äôs attacks on our northern neighbor ‚Äì and New York could be caught in the middle.

The trade war between America and Canada has already had significant impacts on New York industries from agriculture to manufacturing, and if the situation spirals, especially following Carney‚Äôs meeting with President Donald Trump on Tuesday, it could make things even worse for the state.

Chris Kirkey, director of the Center for the Study of Canada and Institute on Qu√©bec Studies at SUNY Plattsburgh, believes that Carney won‚Äôt let things escalate.

Kirkey told City & State: ‚ÄúMark Carney is committed to trade with New York and trade with the United States. He's not a protectionist. He's one who believes in the value of markets, but particularly free markets.‚Äù

Assembly Member Billy Jones said that even if Carney does manage to mend fences and repair the way that some Canadians are beginning to view the U.S. and New York, much of the economic damage is done.

Jones said that Canadian officials understand the situation that New York is in, but new policies in response to the trade war, like limiting barriers for interprovincial commerce and labor supply, are already in motion.

Gov. Kathy Hochul and other governors in the northeast also invited Canadian officials to the U.S. in a bid to strengthen cross border ties.

Rep. Josh Riley, who represents a large rural district in upstate New York, is hopeful that Carney will recognize the situation and negotiate for a more equitable trade agreement.

Riley said: ‚ÄúMy hope is that this summer, when the United States, Mexico and Canada trade agreement is up for review, there's an opportunity there to renegotiate some parts of it in a way that does two things: first, provide certainty and support for Upstate New York's farmers, and then second, brings good manufacturing jobs back home.‚Äù

Chris Kirkey said: ‚ÄúI think New York has to just once again remind folks that this relationship is really a positive one for New York state.‚Äù

resumen:
The Port of Virginia supports 1.29 million jobs, employs 565,000 people in Virginia and accounts for over $100 billion added to the national economy, 2021 data says.

Local experts and officials don‚Äôt have a clear picture of how the Trump administration‚Äôs tariff policy will affect the Port of Virginia and the many thousands of jobs connected to it, but ports across the country are bracing for a significant slowdown in traffic.

Impacts will be felt between May and July, according to Vinod Agarwal, a professor of economics at Old Dominion University and deputy director for ODU‚Äôs Dragas Center for Economic Analysis and Policy.

The tariffs are levied on ‚Äújust about every trade lane we have,‚Äù said Joe Harris, a spokesperson for the Port of Virginia.

Port of Virginia CEO Stephen Edwards said, ‚Äúvery plainly, it‚Äôs hard to know.‚Äù

Agarwal said is ‚Äúsimply because everyone knew the tariffs would be taking place in April and if you‚Äôre in the business of importing goods you want to make sure they arrive in time before the tariffs go into effect.‚Äù

Tariffs should lead to a decrease in imports at almost all U.S. ports, not just the Port of Virginia, according to Agarwal.

The effect of the tariffs has not yet been seen in as much detail as is likely to be seen in the next couple of months.

The tariffs will lead to increases in prices, the higher prices will result in decreased demand for these products, so we should see a decline in imports which will of course affect the Port of Virginia, according to Agarwal.

Based on 2021 data, the Port of Virginia accounts for $153 billion added to the United States economy, supports 1.29 million jobs and employs about 565,000 people in Virginia.

title: Trump's tariffs are hurting Tennesseans and the local economy. Here's how | Opinion
content: From job losses and increased costs related to reduced exports, Tennesseans will only be harmed by Trump's tariffs ...
resumen: Economists widely disagree with tariffs as effective economic policy, citing potential harm to efficient industries and overall economic growth. Tariffs are also likely to raise consumer prices and cause job losses in sectors reliant on imports. Tariffs can negatively impact Tennessee's manufacturing and export-heavy economy, affecting industries like automotive and medical equipment. Over 1,700 economists disagree with tariffs, seeing no credible economic justification for them, and warning that they will only prop up inefficient producers at the expense of more efficient industries. This will undermine economic efficiency, employment, and wage growth in Tennessee. Economists aren‚Äôt convinced by any of the three justifications the Trump Administration advances for tariffs. If Trump‚Äôs goal is job protectionism, then tariffs must be high enough to force Americans to buy American. If revenue is the goal, then tariffs must be low enough so Americans will still pay the tax, which means they will not protect American jobs. If negotiation towards free trade is the goal, then neither job nor revenue objectives will be achieved. Tariffs protect some American jobs in a few sectors by destroying far more American jobs in other sectors. Dockworkers, truckers, and delivery drivers are the first Americans to lose their jobs under tariffs. Next comes job losses at American firms that import inputs, such as materials, parts, and compounds, to produce goods and services. Nearly 60% of our imports are inputs, so tariffs will substantially raise costs for American companies. These costs will be passed along to consumers, resulting in fewer sales and, thus, job loss. Steel tariffs to protect jobs in the steel industry caused massive job losses in the American automobile, motorcycle, and farming equipment sectors. Tariffs slash foreign investment in the American economy. Tariffs make American goods and services more expensive, hurting our exporting industries and reducing foreign investment in our country. Retaliatory tariffs, which can be expected, only serve to amplify these losses. Tariffs are a tax paid by American consumers. Tariffs tend to be a regressive tax because a set tax will fall heavier on the budgets of the poor than the wealthy. No credible estimates come even close to raising enough revenue. America has some of the highest tariffs and non-tariff barriers among our major trading partners. Trump started negotiations not by lowering our tariffs to match our trading partners but by jacking them up across the board. He ripped up previous trade agreements, including one he signed and declared ‚Äúthe fairest, most balanced, and beneficial trade agreement‚Äù ever. Countries like India, China, and Vietnam‚Äîwith per capita GDPs of only $2,500, $12,500, and $4,300 (compared to nearly $83,000 for the US)‚Äîwon‚Äôt be buying our automobiles anytime soon. Tennessee‚Äôs economy, heavily tied to manufacturing and exports, suffers from these ripple effects. The state exported nearly $40 billion in goods in 2024, including $4.25 billion in medical instruments, $2.63 billion in automobiles, and $2.26 billion in computers. Roughly 1/5th of Tennessee‚Äôs jobs are driven by international trade. Trump‚Äôs 2025 ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù tariffs can be expected to slash exports, raise input costs, and reduce competitiveness for firms like Nissan in Smyrna, Jack Daniels in Lynchburg, or Bridgestone in La Vergne. A recent Goldman Sachs report estimated that a 10% tariff alone could destroy five U.S. jobs for every job created, even without retaliation. The U.S. is manufacturing more than it ever has in inflation-adjusted terms. We are the second-largest exporter of manufactured goods in the world and the largest exporter of services. Automation is allowing people worldwide to move out of mundane, low-skilled jobs. Daniel J. Smith is the Director of the Political Economy Research Institute and Professor of Economics at Middle Tennessee State University.

Las empresas espa√±olas manifestaron preocupaci√≥n por las altas tasas de inter√©s y la volatilidad cambiaria en la regi√≥n, a lo que se suma el marco legal y regulatorio, m√°s que el porcentaje de inflaci√≥n en las econom√≠as. Juan Carlos Mart√≠nez L√°zaro, junto al embajador de M√©xico en Espa√±a, la diretora comercial de Iberia, ejecutivos de AUXADI, el director de Civitatis, el diretor de Casa de Am√©rica y el director del IE University. De igual modo, califican como amenaza y riesgo para sus inversiones la inestabilidad pol√≠tica, volatilidad del tiempo de cambio, inseguridad jur√≠dica, desaceleraci√≥n econ√≥mica e inestabilidad social. RD est√° tambi√©n entre los pa√≠ses con menor complejidad tributaria, al quedar en una puntuaci√≥n de 2.90 en una calificaci√≥n del 1 al 5. Las empresas espa√±olas invierten en Iberoam√©rica en 18 sectores, que van desde la construcci√≥n, concesiones, ingenier√≠as, arquitectura; un 17% en industrias de software, tecnolog√≠as y ‚Äústarturps‚Äù tecnol√≥gicas, 10% en industria y manufacturas, 9% en energ√≠a, 5% en autom√≥viles, componentes y construcci√≥n ferroviaria, 5% en servicios bancarios y 35% en otros servicios. title: Trump says US should to stop ‚Äòsubsidising‚Äô Canada as trade talks continue
content: The US leader says it‚Äôs hard to justify the US$200 billion deficit, including defence spending benefiting the nation.
resumen: WASHINGTON: President Donald Trump on Tuesday said the US should stop ‚Äúsubsidising‚Äù Canada, as he hosted the country‚Äôs recently reelected premier Mark Carney for talks in Washington. Canada has been caught up in the new administration‚Äôs stop-start tariff rollout, which has hit goods not covered under an existing free trade arrangement with levies of up to 25%. Canada‚Äôs autos, steel, and aluminum exports have also been hit by the tariffs. ‚ÄúWe have a tremendous deficit with Canada,‚Äù Trump told reporters during an event at the White House, with Carney seated just a few feet away. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to justify subsidising Canada to the tune of maybe US$200 billion a year,‚Äù he said, adding: ‚ÄúWe protect Canada militarily, and we always will.‚Äù The US‚Äô trade deficit with Canada was US$63.3 billion last year, according to the US trade representative‚Äôs office. The far higher figure of US$200 billion often cited by Trump also takes into account how much US defence spending benefits Canada, a member of the Trump transition team told CNN in mid-January, ahead of his return to office. Returning to the issue of trade, Trump said America‚Äôs northern neighbour would soon have to ‚Äútake care of itself economically.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt really want cars from Canada, and we put tariffs on cars from Canada,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd at a certain point, it won‚Äôt make economic sense for Canada to build those cars.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe really don‚Äôt want Canadian steel, and we don‚Äôt want Canadian aluminium and various other things, because we want to be able to do it ourselves,‚Äù he added. The White House previously estimated that around 38% of Canadian imports to the US and around half of all Mexican imports, are covered by the existing US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) and are currently not subject to the sweeping tariffs. A large part of Canada‚Äôs US imports not covered by the USMCA exemption are energy products, which currently face a lower 10% tariff rate. The USMCA is due for review next year.

resumen:
Al terminar una laguna fiscal estadounidense, los fabricantes de ropa que venden a Estados Unidos se ven obligados a considerar mercados alternativos o ubicaciones m√°s baratas dentro y fuera de China.

Liu Miao ha vendido ropa en Amazon a compradores mayoristas de Estados Unidos durante los √∫ltimos cinco a√±os. Ese comercio se ha interrumpido bruscamente.

Liu es propietario de una peque√±a f√°brica en Cant√≥n, que ha sido durante mucho tiempo el centro de la competitiva industria china de confecci√≥n de ropa. √âl y otros gerentes de f√°brica, que ya lidiaban con m√°rgenes de ganancia estrechos, dijeron la semana pasada que la combinaci√≥n de los aranceles y el nuevo impuesto del presidente Donald Trump sobre las importaciones baratas hab√≠a afectado profundamente sus negocios. Los costos a lo largo de la cadena de suministro tambi√©n son m√°s elevados.

Los aranceles han hecho imposible que Liu siga vendiendo en Amazon, donde antes ganaba alrededor de 1 d√≥lar por cada prenda, pero ahora solo obtiene 50 centavos. Y sent√≠a que no pod√≠a recortar el salario de sus empleados, dijo Liu. ‚ÄúAhora mismo no se puede vender nada a Estados Unidos‚Äù, dijo Liu. ‚ÄúLos aranceles son demasiado altos‚Äù.

Plataformas como Amazon, Shein y Temu llevaron la vasta cadena de suministro manufacturero de China a las puertas del mundo. Estos mercados en l√≠nea hicieron posible que miles de peque√±as f√°bricas de Cant√≥n llegaran a compradores de Estados Unidos. Y como los paquetes de menos de 800 d√≥lares pod√≠an entrar en Estados Unidos libres de impuestos, las f√°bricas y, a su vez, las plataformas pudieron cobrar precios muy bajos.

Las exportaciones han sido uno de los principales motores del crecimiento econ√≥mico de China en los √∫ltimos a√±os. Los negocios han ido especialmente bien en el comercio electr√≥nico.

Pero ahora que las tensiones comerciales han obligado a las dos mayores econom√≠as del mundo a separarse, muchas empresas de Cant√≥n se enfrentan a un punto de inflexi√≥n.

Los aranceles agravan los diversos problemas a los que se enfrentan los fabricantes de ropa. Cada vez es m√°s dif√≠cil obtener ganancias ya que el gobierno chino ha tenido dificultades para conseguir que los consumidores gasten m√°s tras el hundimiento del mercado inmobiliario del pa√≠s. Sin el aumento del valor de la vivienda, muchas personas chinas restringen su gasto.

Esto perjudic√≥ los negocios de Zhang Chen, quien pose√≠a seis tiendas de ropa en la provincia central de Hubei. Pero cuando los compradores no volvieron tras la pandemia de covid y los alquileres se mantuvieron altos, decidi√≥ cerrarlas todas.

‚ÄúEn 2020, el negocio no se recuperaba, y en 2021, segu√≠a sin hacerlo. En 2022, cuando segu√≠a igual, parec√≠a que no iba a recuperarse nunca‚Äù, dijo Zhang. Ahora gana unos 100 d√≥lares al d√≠a entregando prendas reci√©n cosidas en los puntos de recolecci√≥n de Shein, cerca del aeropuerto.

Las f√°bricas de Cant√≥n no son los talleres automatizados que producen veh√≠culos el√©ctricos ni los campus de fabricaci√≥n de semiconductores que son clave en el esfuerzo que China lleva a√±os realizando para garantizar su resistencia geopol√≠tica mediante la tecnolog√≠a avanzada. Sin embargo, las f√°bricas de ropa de China emplean a millones de trabajadores que se afanan por ganarse la vida.

Pero en abril, despu√©s de que la empresa le encargara la mitad de eso, empez√≥ a trasladar su l√≠nea de producci√≥n a la provincia vecina de Jiangxi. Ya no pod√≠a pagar el alquiler en Cant√≥n.

Liu dijo que Shein ofrec√≠a incentivos para ayudar a cubrir el costo de trasladar las operaciones a Vietnam, y √©l lo hab√≠a considerado, ‚Äúpero entonces los aranceles en Vietnam tambi√©n se hicieron a√∫n m√°s altos‚Äù.

Dijo que tambi√©n hab√≠a intentado encontrar compradores en TikTok y Temu, pero los pedidos hab√≠an bajado en todas las plataformas. ‚ÄúTodos est√°n cayendo, y nosotros solo esperamos y observamos‚Äù, dijo Liu.

Temu dijo el viernes que hab√≠a dejado de enviar productos de China directamente a compradores de Estados Unidos.

Dado que los consumidores chinos son prudentes a la hora de gastar, a las f√°bricas les resultar√° dif√≠cil vender en su pa√≠s tanto como exportaban.

El gobierno chino ha estado animando a las plataformas nacionales de comercio electr√≥nico a ayudar a las peque√±as empresas a vender a su mercado nacional. Pero, dado que los consumidores chinos son prudentes a la hora de gastar, a las f√°bricas les resultar√° dif√≠cil vender en el pa√≠s tanto como exportaban.

Han Junxiu, quien vende calcetines novedosos en Shein y Temu, dijo que dudaba que el gobierno estadounidense s√∫bitamente pudiera empezar a cobrar aranceles sobre los paquetes de bajo precio, los cuales hab√≠an estado entrando en Estados Unidos a un ritmo de cuatro millones al d√≠a.

‚ÄúNo creo que sea tan realista‚Äù, dijo Han tras cerrar su puesto por la noche en la Feria de Cant√≥n, la feria anual de exportaci√≥n de la provincia.

Este es exactamente el tipo de cosas que los estadounidenses seguir√°n necesitando comprar a las empresas chinas, dijo Han. ‚Äú¬øD√≥nde m√°s van a comprar todo esto?‚Äù, pregunt√≥.

El resultado: par√°lisis operativa, riesgos legales para funcionarios y una potencial ca√≠da de recaudaci√≥n estimada entre US$ 395.000 millones y US$ 2,4 billones en la pr√≥xima d√©cada. Trump presiona a Powell para que baje tasas. La tensi√≥n se nota: la Fed busca se√±ales de prudencia, mientras la Casa Blanca eleva el ruido institucional en campa√±a. Trump dice que no va a despedir a Powell. La tarifa del 145% sobre productos chinos no solo encarece el consumo dom√©stico: tambi√©n genera tensiones pol√≠ticas en Asia y un realineamiento de las cadenas globales. China ha logrado proyectar una imagen de estabilidad frente al giro err√°tico estadounidense y, por ahora, parece tener la sart√©n por el mango: sus socios regionales, sin alinear totalmente, tampoco quieren romper. La presi√≥n arancelaria china ‚Äîideada para castigar a Pek√≠n‚Äî le da a China una inusual capacidad de decisi√≥n: Trump necesita que Xi "haga el primer gesto", y Xi no muestra apuro. Una pol√≠tica fiscal contradictoria, una pol√≠tica monetaria en suspenso, y una pol√≠tica comercial con m√°s volatilidad que beneficios visibles. Resultado: alta incertidumbre y baja gobernabilidad. La falta de previsibilidad en la relaci√≥n con EE.UU. ha congelado inversiones clave en semiconductores, biotecnolog√≠a y nube industrial. EE.UU. alterna avances estructurales (como las sanciones a Huawei o la reconfiguraci√≥n de la cadena de chips) con se√±ales err√°ticas y una diplomacia cada vez m√°s introspectiva. title: Trump‚Äôs tariffs deal a blow to the bottom line of US companies
content: Businesses are suspending or lowering their earnings and profit forecasts due to uncertainty, higher costs, and an economic slowdown ...
resumen:
U.S. President Donald Trump is presenting the trade war as a way to protect American industry from foreign competition. The tariffs, however, are directly affecting his own companies‚Äô bottom lines. Dozens of major businesses across multiple sectors have warned in their first-quarter earnings reports of the impact they will suffer from Trump‚Äôs new trade policy.

The blow to companies‚Äô earnings and profits comes primarily through two channels: the direct effect on businesses with a global supply chain that import goods from countries subject to the new tariffs, and the effect of uncertainty and loss of confidence, which translates into a slowdown in consumer spending and the economy in general.

Berkshire Hathaway warned of the ‚Äúconsiderable uncertainty‚Äù introduced by the trade war. The group, a conglomerate with companies in numerous sectors, warned in its quarterly report of the potential impact through changes in product costs, supply chain efficiency, and customer demand for its products and services. Around three out of four companies have alluded to the tariffs in their earnings reports.

General Motors warned of a $4 billion to $5 billion impact on its financials this year. The company lowered its adjusted earnings before interest and tax from a previous range of $11.2 billion to $12.5 billion, down to $8.2 billion to $10.1 billion. Ford suspended its annual financial guidance on Monday due to tariff-related uncertainty, after admitting a $1.5 billion impact on earnings, despite taking steps to mitigate an additional $1 billion.

Apple estimated that the impact of the current measures would still result in an additional cost of approximately $900 million in the second quarter. CEO Tim Cook hinted that the impact could be greater in subsequent quarters.

Amazon stated that its future results could be affected by ‚Äútariff and trade policies.‚Äù Andy Jassy, president and CEO, said on a call with analysts, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to tell what‚Äôs going to happen with tariffs right now. It‚Äôs hard to tell where they‚Äôre going to settle and when they‚Äôre going to settle.‚Äù

Colgate-Palmolive estimates that the tariffs will cause $200 million in increased costs. Procter & Gamble indicated that it is even considering reformulating its products to try to mitigate the cost increases (and price increases) resulting from the new tariffs, while lowering its sales forecast to between $1.7 billion and $3.4 billion for the year. Clorox also lowered its growth forecast on Monday.

PepsiCo lowered its full-year adjusted profit forecast due to uncertainty, rising supply chain costs, and signs of weakening consumer sentiment. McDonald‚Äôs has already suffered its biggest drop in sales since the pandemic in the first quarter.

Airbnb and Booking.com cited increased economic uncertainty when they released forecasts that disappointed the market. American Airlines and Delta Air Lines have withdrawn their 2025 forecasts, citing uncertainty stemming from Trump‚Äôs trade policies, while Southwest Airlines and United Airlines are halting their growth plans in anticipation of lower demand for domestic leisure travel.

The head of steelmaker Nucor, Leon Topalian, expressed optimism about demand following the 25% tariffs imposed on aluminum and steel from his foreign competitors.
